Dead Island: Riptide is the direct sequel to the first part and picks up where its predecessor left off. After leaving the holiday island of Banoi, the survivors land by helicopter on a military ship, where they are promptly captured and imprisoned. During the uncomfortable journey through a tropical storm, the frigate runs aground on a reef and strands on a tropical island - and we are forced to fight our way through the same scenario again. The melee and weapon arsenal has been expanded, which overall is a good thing. Great gory fun at first, but otherwise the game plays too quickly like its predecessor and, thanks to little variety, degenerates into pure frustration and hard work later at some point. Unfortunately, a lot of potential was wasted unnecessarily, too many half-baked ideas and overall repetative. Yes, it's an okay-game, but I would have liked a lot more effort and story-technical depth. Let's see how the third part turns out.

After almost 8 years since its release, Dead Island: Riptide continues to captivate in 2024. Its immersive blend of action, survival, and zombie combat provides a thrilling experience. While the graphics may not be cutting-edge, they still hold their appeal, and the variety of characters and weapons ensures diverse gameplay. Although some aspects may feel dated, the engaging plot and the intensity of the fights make it a solid choice for fans of the genre.

[b]Disclaimer[/b]: I did not progress very far in this game since the motion sickness I received while playing this game was way worse than in it's predecessor.


[b]TL;DR:[/b] It is basically the same game as the predecessor just at a new location. The gameplay get's stale pretty fast. Head bobbing and fov stutters are way worse than in the predecessor. The upgrading system has been improved slightly.


[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
[*] An additional upgrading path has been added that levels upon using certain equipment
[*] A lot of sidequests wherever you go. Most of them are basically the same, but still believable. Everybody would require mostly the same help in such situation.
[*] Navigation via the minimap is ok in most cases
[*] Hack n Slash works decent
[*] Various weapons and mods that you can apply to "fake" diversity
[*] Potential Co-Op
[*] Your rewards from quests and loot scales with your level
[*] Enemies scale with your level - so you can remain in the same area while the loot and xp gains grow
[/list]


[b]Cons:[/b]
[*] Head bobbing and fov lag when you run around can cause motion sickness. It got way worse than in the predecessor.
[*] Voice acting is terrible
[*] Graphics are meh
[*] Character models are disgustingly ugly and the most scary thing in the entire game - no wonder you get attacked non stop
[*] No way to adjust difficulty
[*] Can't zoom out from the map far enough to see the entire map, so you are constantly shifting the map around to search for locations ....
[*] Gunplay is one of the worst I have ever seen
[list]
[*] Upon ADS-ing there is a crazy aimbot on enemies bodies (never their head!) - even through walls
[*] There is an even bigger aimsupport whenever you aim next to enemies, that slows down your mouse movement so that you have to wipe across your entire mousepad to switch from somebody, you are aiming to, to another one that is literally right next to them. Same when you want to correct your ADS-aimbot from chest to head. It is just tedious and unreliable
[*] Not ADS-ing works in close range but later in the game it is required since the weapons are not accurate enough when you don't ADS ...... So you can't compensate it with your own skill. FUN
[*] No way to disable the aimbot and aimsupport
[*] No way to adjust the ADS sensitivity separately
[/list]

Realistically, if this was a real zombie apocalypse, we wouldn't wait until we're at a "certain" level to use weapons. As a fan of the original Dead Island game, I was eagerly anticipating the release of Dead Island Riptide. And I have to say, it did not disappoint. This expansion is a perfect follow-up to the first game, continuing the story of the survivors and adding new elements that keep the game feeling fresh and exciting.

One of the first things that struck me about Dead Island Riptide was the improvements in graphics and gameplay. The graphics are even more stunning than the first game, with vibrant and detailed environments that really immerse you in the zombie-infested island. The gameplay also feels smoother and more polished, making combat and movement feel more fluid and natural.

But what sets Dead Island Riptide apart from the first game is the new island of Palanai. This new location adds a whole new dimension to the game, with different landscapes, dangerous new enemies, and interesting side quests to discover. Exploring this new island is an adventure in itself and adds even more hours of gameplay to an already lengthy game.

The characters from the original game also make a return in Riptide, and their stories continue to evolve in interesting and unexpected ways. It was great to see how they have grown and changed since the events of the first game, and also to meet new characters who bring their own unique flavor to the group dynamic.

One of the things that made the original Dead Island so popular was its open-world, RPG-style gameplay. And this aspect is still present and well-executed in Riptide. The game gives you the freedom to explore, make choices, and improve your character's skills and weapons, making each playthrough a unique and personal experience.

Of course, a game like Dead Island Riptide wouldn't be complete without its signature, gory combat. And once again, the game delivers on this front. The variety of weapons available, from the classic machete to electrified axes, makes for some truly satisfying zombie-slaying action. And the addition of new special infected, like the Screamer and the Boomer, adds new challenges and strategies to the gameplay.

Overall, Dead Island Riptide is a solid expansion to an already legendary game. It does an excellent job of building upon the foundation of the first game, while also bringing fresh and exciting elements to the table. Whether you are a fan of the original or new to the Dead Island series, this game is a must-play for any zombie game enthusiast.

Techland really knows how to make even more terrible sequel. 

Cons
1. This game inherits all the bugs from the first game and becomes even more frustrating. 
2. They added some tower defense crap too.  How desperate when people are out of ideas.
3. Have you tried mines? There is the animation for laying mines, but not every time is a mine laid, what an embarrassing failure. 
4. Mobs teleporting, sometimes into the sky and fall to their death LOLOL
5. Mobs teleporting, into wonderlands, along with your fully upgraded modded throwing weapons. 
6. In the first game, there are only a few occasions where the runners instant respawn, but in this game, Techland decides to spam that mechanic. How desperate when people are out of ideas.
7. Somehow weapon mods are even harder to find and more useless.
8. Techland decides their game shall be a boss-fight game, and adds tons of bosses. "Popular games have bosses, we should too" right? Well other games' bosses are very very rewarding. 
9. (Edit) tried Logan today, and they nerfed his damage buff by 50%, instant-kill buff by 67%, and critical-rate buff by a whopping 90%.You have to understand, unlike other characters, Logan's skills are all over the place, weapon-throw is the only thing he's good at. Riptide buffed all other characters by adding this weapon familiarity system, and at the same time nerfed Logan's damage. That's basically double nerf. Techland? More like TechFailure.
10. (Edit again) I forced myself to use Logan in the first base defense battle. Holy moly, he went from Hero to Zero. He basically did no damage, died twice, and didn't make it in time to save his mates (my first playthrough was John, he made all the base defense like child's play). Logan is officially the weakest in Dead Island Riptide. He's good at basically nothing but throwing, and Techland took that away from him. This is further proof Techland is worse than amateur. I will definitely put this studio on my block list.

Hello friends, today I will tell you about the game Dead Island: Riptide Definitive Edition. This game is about the adventures of a group of survivors caught in a zombie outbreak on a tropical island. The game was released in 2016 and was highly appreciated for its graphics, gameplay and atmosphere.

The best part of the game is that there are plenty of weapons and equipment to kill zombies with. Knives, axes, hammers, pistols, rifles, bombs... You name it. You can also modify your weapons to make them more powerful and fun. For example, you can fry zombies crispy with an electric knife. 😁

Another great thing about the game is that you can play co-op with up to four people. It's easier and more fun to go zombie hunting with your friends. The story is not bad either, the characters' pasts and the relationships between them are interesting. The atmosphere of the game is also very successful, creating a contrast between the beauty of the island and the horror of the zombies.

Of course, there are some things I didn't like about the game. First of all, the optimization of the game is not very good. Fps drops in some places and stutters in others. If you want to play the game on high settings, you need a good system. Also, the artificial intelligence of the game is not very smart. Sometimes the zombies don't notice you, sometimes they crash into walls, and sometimes they hang in the air. These situations can be both funny and frustrating. 😅

In conclusion, Dead Island: Riptide Definitive Edition is a good option for those looking for a zombie-themed action game. The graphics, gameplay and atmosphere of the game will satisfy you. The game's optimization and artificial intelligence are a bit problematic, but if you play with friends, you can ignore these issues. The game is currently 85% off on Steam, don't miss it. I liked the game, I hope you will like it too. I wish you all good games. 👍

Summary:
"Dead Island: Riptide" is an action role-playing survival horror video game developed by Techland and published by Deep Silver. It serves as a sequel to the original "Dead Island" game, continuing the story of a group of survivors battling hordes of zombies on a tropical island.

The game picks up immediately after the events of the first game, with the survivors finding themselves stranded on another island in the Banoi archipelago after narrowly escaping the zombie outbreak on the island of Banoi. The main characters - Logan, Purna, Sam B, and Xian Mei - along with a new character named John Morgan, must once again fight for survival against the relentless zombie horde and various other dangers.

Players explore the island, completing quests, scavenging for resources, and crafting weapons to fend off the infected and hostile human factions. The game features a combination of melee combat, gunplay, and RPG elements, allowing players to customize their characters' abilities and skills as they progress through the story.

Throughout the game, players encounter different types of zombies with unique abilities and strengths, as well as diverse environments ranging from dense jungles to flooded towns. The narrative unfolds as the survivors uncover the mysteries behind the outbreak while facing internal conflicts and external threats.

"Dead Island: Riptide" emphasizes cooperative gameplay, allowing up to four players to join forces in the campaign, enabling teamwork to tackle challenges and missions together. The game received mixed reviews, with praise for its co-op experience, combat mechanics, and atmosphere, but criticism for technical issues and repetitive gameplay elements inherited from its predecessor.

This is my review of Dead Island Definitive Edition: 

https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561197992494675/recommended/383150/

Most things said there apply to this one, too.

So it is quite the same as Dead Island but with a few more bugged jumps and moves. Purnas special move is running like a moron towards zombies and flailing her weapon around uncontrollably, often not hitting anything with it because often she is simply glitching through them...

One difference is that you start in the Jungle in this one. It is a jungle that is a bit less horribly boring than the one in Dead Island, but nonetheless, it is boring.

One positive thing is that there are actually some new zombies.

The game is riddled with meaningless and useless generic side quests that can be completely ignored without any consequences. The main story quests are insanely monotone and repetitive. Even worse than the first Dead Island.
The side quests mean NOTHING. They do not change anything. You rescue somebody? Oh he will not even move. They just keep STANDING there. Why not alter the world at least a bit the more people you save? They are simply there to be saved and give you a bit of cash or items. Maybe after saving a certain amount add some allies or patrols to the game?

Your main occupation is to clear proper home bases for some meaningless and badly done characters you do not care about to move in for the duration of 1-2 main quests and then repeat that over and over again until the game is done. This was used so excessively and often, that I simply wanted them to die. They were just an anchor that dragged out the game a bit longer.

There is one character, I do not know his name because none of them is worth even memorizing, but he was the throwing weapon vendor. [spoiler] He was selling good grenades early on but he dies early. [/spoiler] So maybe stock on grenades in early game. 

They are anyway the best weapon until maybe 15 minutes before the end.

There are insane sound bugs, especially in co-op mode. And sometimes, some chest locators from quests are constantly beeping and heard in the entire map.

The story is just idiotic. 

When you look at the positive reviews, remember that less than 20% of players actually finished the game and just stopped at some point playing it. Same as it was with Dead Island.
Most of them simply tried it out a bit, killed some Zombies, and were happy about that.

If you simply want to play a game without a brain and shoot some zombies with the illusion of a story, meaningless NPC characters who are 100% generic and replaceable, a sh*t ton of bugs, and side quests that don't mean anything this game is meant for you.

After giving the Dead Island franchise another chance and playing this one I am quite certain I will only buy Dead Island 2 if it is 5 bucks or less and then so only to see the new mess Techland and Deep Silver have done. Maybe that is actually their selling strategy.

It's more Dead Island, Good and Bad. 
Do I recommend it? yes and no. If you liked Dead Island then yes, this is more of that, with some more problems. If you didn't or you haven't played Dead Island then its an absolute no.
I had a ton of fun with the original, go play that first. This DLC is more Dead Island but it introduces a new Island and a few more problems or highlights the problems of the original even more. 
The base game was fun and dumb, not too hard and not too easy, this one ramps up the difficulty a fair bit to the point where it makes it not as fun, at least to me. There are plenty of Zombs that power through your attacks, so you will take damage regardless, and with the amount of Zombs that this game throws at you that will mean death. Also I feel like some of the Boss' are way over powered, I was above level of a Boss i fought and my attacks were still barely hurting him while it only took a few hits from him to kill me. Luckily this game only sets you back a tiny bit so you can mostly brute force your way through. 

Anyways TLDR if you liked the original then yes play this with a bit of more patience. If you didnt like or havent plyaed the OG then go do that first. Overall I still had fun but that's admittedly because i have a guilty pleasure for these types of games. so yes I recommend with some caveats

I'll put this as a lightly not recommended title, as it's an inferior sequel to the original title that was clearly rushed out of the gate. While most new additions additions, such as a new character and fist-fighting weapons, are welcome and show improvement on the first outing, others, such as the boat segments only used for the first act, just didn't work and wound up being tedious. The story is a direct continuation of the first game which is nice, and it does give player characters more direct involvement, but it suffers from being a bit one-note, without much in the way of surprises or even new characters (I suppose it's a bit like a stage play to be honest). When the plot never moves beyond looking for ways to improve the home base, moving camp, or pursuing possible ways to escape the island, it's hard to remain invested. On the plus side, most side quests are either related to this goal or incidental good deeds you can do along the way, so they feel much more immediate and relevant (probably the most side quests I've done in one of games). On the plus side, it's playable in its entirety in co-op along with the first game, so that might be fun. Outside of that, compared to the first entry and especially Dying Light, you're completely fine skipping this one, there's really nothing you'll see that isn't done in DL in either a superior or more engaging/smooth way. Still nice to see the way the gameplay has progressed, a good reminder that home-runs often need a few iterations before the sweet spot.

After playing through Dead Island and Dead Island Riptide, I cant recommend this game. 

If you get this game for free it's still not worth it. Please don't even bother. This game is honestly one of the worst I've ever played. The only thing that made it mildly entertaining was playing it co-op. Otherwise the 'Story' (because of a clear lack of imaginative writing) and side quests were completely pointless, felt like they had little, to no impact and gave pathetic rewards. At points it truly felt like the dev's had a good idea, then just gave up. 

(SIDE QUEST SPOILER WARNING) One side quest we thought actually had some imagination was the one where this guy asks you to find a superhero cape, superhero fish and superhero shoes. We thought this would lead somewhere funny (finally a side quest that we actually wanted to do). Yet, when we handed it in, he didn't change in appearance, he said "follow me" ran down the path (taking about 10 steps) we defended him against 2 zombies and he teleported back to where he originally was, said he wasn't interested in being a hero and just made the entire side quest completely pointless as he didn't even give us a reward. 

Don't even get me started on the bugs. There were times I was jumping over an obstacle to proceed, my character got stuck and I just died. There was items falling through the floor. Zombies stuck in a T pose. I could climb ladders then be teleported back to the bottom of the ladder. The sound bugs... oh god the constant sound bugs. You could hear a grenade going off as if it's right next to you, but it's my partner on the other side of the city. Or the constant beeping right in my ear as a side quest is telling me to head to the other side of the map to pick up a supply drop. 

This game is by far not worth it. Honestly, Dead Island should stay just as it is. Dead.

Dead Island Riptide really feels like a DLC/Expansion stretched into a full-length game. It is a direct continuation with the story picked up immediately after the first game’s ending. Don’t expect drastic improvements or variations to the core gameplay. 

It mostly stays the same with minor tweaks such as a few new enemies, weapons, vehicles, etc. It looks rough in some areas. You can feel that the game had been rushed to meet the deadline with reused or repurposed assets, stiff animations, etc. The story is mediocre at best. There isn’t much to say. I mostly stayed for (still) satisfying melee combat and dismemberment system though.

Greetings, fellow gamers and furries alike! From the icy realms of HowlStrom, I, Kiba Snowpaw, have ventured into the tropical paradise turned nightmare of Banoi in Dead Island: Riptide Definitive Edition. With over 36 years of gaming experience under my furry belt, I bring you an in-depth, dramatic, and action-packed review of this game, with a touch of furry flair.

The Setting:
Imagine a world where the serene beauty of a tropical island meets the chilling horror of a zombie apocalypse. The juxtaposition of paradise and terror is a sight to behold. As I traversed the island, I couldn't help but draw parallels to my icy homeland of HowlStrom - both places of beauty, yet fraught with danger.

The Gameplay Experience:
The adrenaline rush of smashing, slicing, and surviving against hordes of the undead is unparalleled. The game's melee combat is visceral, making every swing, every hit, and every kill feel personal. The cooperative multiplayer mode adds another layer of depth, allowing for strategic team play and camaraderie.

Features and Graphics:
The remastered edition boasts improved graphics, game models, and a photorealistic lighting system. As an Ice Wolf with a keen eye for detail, I was particularly impressed by the game's atmospheric immersion. The shadows, the lights, and the overall ambiance transported me right into the heart of the action.

The Story and Characters:
The narrative picks up from where Dead Island left off, thrusting players into another thrilling adventure. The addition of John, the hand-to-hand combat expert, adds a fresh dynamic to the gameplay. Each character, from Sam B to Xian Mei, has a unique backstory and skill set, making for varied gameplay experiences.

Critique and Furry Insights:
While the game offers a plethora of features and improvements, it's not without its flaws. Some bugs and glitches from the original remain, which can be a tad frustrating. However, as a seasoned gamer, I've learned to look beyond minor imperfections and appreciate the broader experience.

From a furry perspective, the game's themes of survival, camaraderie, and bravery resonate deeply. Just as we furries stick together in the face of adversity, so do the characters in Dead Island: Riptide. Their determination to survive against all odds mirrors the furry community's resilience and spirit.

Conclusion:
Dead Island: Riptide Definitive Edition is more than just a game; it's an experience. It's a tale of survival, friendship, and bravery set against the backdrop of a paradise turned hell. For those who've played the original, this remastered edition offers a fresh perspective. For newcomers, it's a thrilling introduction to the world of Dead Island.

In the words of a wise Ice Wolf from HowlStrom, "In the face of danger, we find our true strength." Whether you're battling zombies on Banoi or facing challenges in the real world, remember to stand tall, stay strong, and always keep your furry spirit alive.

Howl on, fellow gamers!
-Kiba Snowpaw, the Furry Ice Wolf of HowlStrom.

A definite step up from the first with regards to a whole bunch of little things that you don't notice until they stop ticking. More zombies prowling around and in bigger groups, guns no longer suck, every weapon category levels up so you aren't bolted to a specific playstyle the whole game. More of an upgraded expansion pack that you can blast through in an evening if you ignore all the side stuff. Some critiques, though; Boats suck bosses suck. Maybe it's just me, but I would rather trek through swamps than get stuck on every tree branch, zombie, and errant mud blobs. And the bosses are just spongey, regenerating tanks that are boring as hell to fight. Anyway, taking apart zombies with your bare hands is always fun, so I recommend playing Dying Light, DL2, or this if you feel saucy.

[h1]Dead Island 2 is on release, Let's not forget this one.[/h1]
[quote][b]Rating:[/b] 8.5/10[/quote]
This game continues from where Dead Island 1 left the story. It's very similar to Dead Island 1, which is practically Dying Light without Parkour. The story was ok but the gameplay was as awesome as before.

The main issue with this game is it's frustrating at times especially due to its bug and navigation. You will enjoy all its zombie killing with modified brutal skull reaping weapons but during traversal in between main and side missions, the navigation route will suddenly disappear almost all the time! The minimap has no real map in it so you will get mad opening the main map again and again!

Also, I found a bug in few initial missions if you explore more and reach the point that you are supposed to reach in the later checkpoint, the game will skip the previous checkpoint which logically will not make much sense. I also encountered 2-3 cases where direction to objectives (side missions) were either too dumb or totally wrong for which I had to rely on Google lol.

Apart from these, the game is awesome if you want more of Dead Island or Dying Light but you will miss parkour so much. Remember you can import your character and unlocked skills levels from the previous Dead Island which I realised after finishing the game... -_-

It was okay overall, most of the issues with the first game are still present and they also managed to break the enhanced navigation, making going around the maze-like jungle and cities so painful. I know you can just look at the map, but it was just a lot more convenient having it.

The new areas and voice acting are pretty cool, so I’ll give them some credit for that, the story is also slightly more interesting and better presented since the protagonists speak a lot more. The soundtrack surprisingly caught my attention too, it has some really good tracks.

I do have a soft spot for this series and it was pretty fun getting all of the achievements, it’s just that it could’ve been a lot better with a few tweaks. You’ll most likely enjoy it if you liked the first game and felt like playing more of it.

You'll also probably die 10 times more in this, there's a LOT of unfairness and it's overall more difficult than the previous game, which isn't that surprising considering it's a sequel.

Cranks up the mayhem. More engagement with characters & environments. 

A worthy sequel.

A small yet significant evolution in some key ways from the original game, at a mild cost. It's neither as disastrously buggy nor (alas) quite as ambitious, epic, and visually attractive. However, it's playable and doesn't  wreak constant frustration as it forgets your quest progress and sets you back (sometimes) hours of playtime, as the original did for me. 

The maps are less expansive and breathtaking, but there are cool little surprises and hidden areas to be found. Walkers and Infected are less overpowered and won't mob you to death at every opportunity as they did previously. If you're okay w/ wearing out your "kick" key, and don't mind running from larger groups/luring enemies away to whittle them down, you can progress w/ reasonable ease. Combat is tense and fun, but as long as you're not leaping into ludicrous situations, you'll die much less  frequently than in the first game. Vehicles are far more valuable this time out - they rack up the kills nicely and I've yet to have one get damaged and break down on me. Quest waypoints on the minimap are as useless as ever but I don't mind wandering around, exploring, and just coming upon my objectives. 

I recall the character animations (both human NPCs and zombies) being more detailed and cool last time - there's some highly busted looking human survivors wandering around this game. No idea what that's about.   

I paid three bucks for it and I'm more than getting my money's worth. If it ends up bugging out fatally at some point, I'll update this review, but so far, it's delivering all the sun-drenched zombie-slaying mayhem I could ask for.

[h1] Review[/h1] 
More of the same. The problem of this game is not only the expectations most people have but also some smaller bugs, which to be fair, the first game wasn't really free of. Instead of advertising it as a big DLC or expansion, it was made to be the next game but absolutely feels like the first.

[u]Gameplay[/u]
Some smaller combat mechanics changed that apparently the first dead island even adapted in its definitive edition. But no idea what exactly is definitive about this one, it didn’t had any DLC really. Otherwise the only new thing is that you now can level up to 70 with like 2-4 new skills, additionally passive levelling and new passive abilities from using a certain weapon type. There is a new dash attack you can skill on, which works almost like the rush from Sam, except worse. 

There is a new vehicle, the boat which works pretty neat. The problem is that it has set spawn locations and if you go in a dungeon you will lose it and have to run to the next spawn location of a boat. There are now a couple of copy paste dungeons, with some strong bosses although they are not specifically different except more tanky.

There is now a better playstyle for ranged combat to the point that it is almost the optimal way as they now spawn way much more ammo for every type, also giving new players who want to level ranged combat flare guns and spear guns early on.

The same pros and cons from the first game are present here aswell, therefore I wont go over them again. The only negative might be that the game is rather short and features less maps. Around 2 major ones and a few very small ones. The big maps have atrocious quick travel systems, making you go back and forth the map a lot due to quests often giving you fetch tasks on the other side of the map.

[u]Story[/u]
You might want to get this to see the relatively weak story continuing. It starts directly after the first game, the boat you go on crashes and you land on another island trying to escape it due to the virus having spread on surrounding islands too. The overall story is weak, with a small twist at the end that I didn’t expect but is rather not that important. It ends in a mechanically weak boss fight where you have to use a random mutagen despite clearly winning the fight. The enemy used a mutagen to get stronger, but physically changed absolutely in no way making it a joke of a fight.

[u]Sound[/u]
Nothing new. Except they constantly play sam b songs over the radio and added a new one.

[u]Graphics[/u]
Nothing changed. Basically exactly the same visuals, except a few new zombie variations and survivor skins.

[u]Conclusion/TL;DR[/u]
Only really useful for completionists. Its more of the same and absolutely fun to continue your characters from the previous game with your friends. But mechanically and gameplay wise so close to the main game. It should have been just advertised as an expansion and even then there is the amount of bugs and subpar story. It doesn't do particularly anything wrong but i feel like i already played through the same game for the most part.

The definitive edition of Dead Island Riptide is hardly an improvement. The gorgeous visuals may distract you from the tedious gameplay and odd bugs for a while, but it doesn’t last forever.

What a fucking surprise, it's the exact same shit as the prequel. The only positives I can give this one is that the story is short and that the achievements don't demand you to play more than one character. However, this one introduces even more dogshit and mushes it right into your face. The fast travel in the previous game was already a mess. This one however changed my perspective on fast travel permanently. Yes, games should absolutely give you the option to fast travel from any point. The open world is so fucking awful that getting around on foot/boat is a complete nightmare. To add insult to injury, they didn't bother fixing the bugs from their previous title. In fact, they just added more. They also decided that the number of annoying enemies wasn't enough so they throw new nuisances at you. And for whatever reason, they decided that enemies should be insanely tankier now. To make this worse, they introduce a brand new type of mission. At various points throughout the story you're forced to survive a mindless horde spam. It's not fun and goes on for far too long. It goes to show that if the devs can't torture you with moronic fetch quests, they instead throw literal feces at you, hoping that you mistake it for a challenge. Thankfully I'm finally done with this shitty franchise. Buying this bundle was a major mistake that I won't repeat for any sequels of this series.

8/10 Overall a big improvement to the first game. The combat and graphics are pretty much the exact same as DI1. There are now new enemies to fight which is nice for a bit more variety. There are technically new additional skill trees which you level up by using different weapon types instead of skill points. The map designs are pretty good, probably a bit better than the first game. The story is massively improved and is overall enjoyable. It's nice that the characters you play as actually talk in game during missions unlike the first game. The only thing that was really bad about this game was the bugs, they are much worse in DIR than DI1. There were a few game breaking bugs, like enemies, which I needed to kill in order to progress the mission, getting stuck in walls so I could not kill them. Also, sometimes mission givers would not talk to me for whatever reason. Overall I really enjoyed it much more than the first game.

I played the original Dead Island back in 2011 and had a blast with it, both in single player and co-op with friends. I recently had the urge to play it again and bought the Dead Island Definitive Edition, reliving my memories as well and loving the improvements made to the game!

After spending 80 or so hours in that game and still loving it, i decided to buy Riptide DE during a sale, understanding it was more of the same but with new maps and some new weapons. Boy, was I wrong.

The combat is pretty much the same, with some minor additions like a instant-kill / high damage QTE when you're on higher ground you can perform on a walker / infected. It sounds great, except its buggy as heck and locks you into the attack animation, after which I have found myself stuck for a few seconds as the animation often bugs out after the attack and you're left helplessly getting wailed on by enemies.

There are some improvements like the addition of throwing weapons now, which can stack up to 30 in a slot so you no longer have to throw your previous normal weapons at the enemy, however, the throwing weapons have pretty low damage, which wouldn't have been a problem for the original DI, but in DI:Riptide, almost every enemy has had a major buff in health, so much that special infected are basically bullet sponges for everything non-fury related.

Your basic special infected like Thugs and Floaters seem to have more than twice the health they had in the original game, even with my imported Logan throwing fully upgraded gold weapons at them, with my weapon proficiency already level 10. Walkers and infected also seem to do more damage, and Riptide absolutely spams the heck out of these. I'm not kidding when I say spam; just leaving the starting village you'll get rushed by about 5 walkers and 3 infected. Its so much that it totally desensitizes me to the zombies, and i no longer feel any sense of terror when I hear an infected scream, and I feel more of a sense of annoyance. 

If the developers made these changes to encourage players to run past enemies instead of fighting, they totally succeeded IMO. Where I used to enjoy killing zombies and still feel a sense of fear and dread when fighting infected in DI:DE, in DI: Riptide DE I just avoid combat where possible, which is hilarious in a game all about killing zombies. Realistic or not, I absolutely hated fighting in DI: Riptide.

In terms of exploration, other than the problem with the spamming of zombies everywhere, many areas of the starting map is filled with water. While traversing water isn't that bad, even on foot, the problem is when you get attacked by zombies. When in water, the player character is significantly slowed down, and in waist high water, you lose the ability to sprint. Unfortunately, the same isn't true for zombies. Even the basic walker is faster than the PC in water, and infected are still able to sprint like Olympic runners while in water.

The spamming of zombies and annoying travel thus contributes to the next problem in the game: The boring sidequests which are basically just fetchquests / go to a location and kill this thing. While DI:DE has the same type of quests, I enjoyed traveling through the different locations in Banoi, and enjoyed the combat, so it wasn't a problem for me. In Riptide however, getting a sidequest that points to a location about 300m away made me groan in pain, knowing the amount of crap I had to wade through just to reach it.
 
Perhaps these are the rantings of a poorly skilled Dead Island player, but I personally think DI: Riptide DE is just a complete chore to play, and if you are a new player looking for some zombie killing action, get DI:DE or DI:2.

For an expansion, this is definitely a solid game. Being able to carry over progression from another Dead Island game is a great feature. The new skills this game adds are also a lot of fun. 

That being said, when you start a new game and carry over progression from the 1st Dead Island, What is kept is your player level and skills. Your inventory items, weapons, money and blueprints are gone. The game still sends zombies that are around your level after you. For characters like Sam B who can make use of blunt weapons, even low quality ones, this isn't too bad. He can still delivery heavy hits and be very effective even with weaker weapons. But for characters like Purna, who specialize is guns, this characters suffers a lot. Since her skills are mostly focused on guns and not melee, she really struggles during the early game. The only gun you get for a good portion of the beginning is a flare gun, which is a fun and effective weapon, but it doesn't stay that way and is sometimes useless when parts of the map are flooded waist high. Thankfully, the weapon upgrade system that levels up specific weapons based on what types you use makes it less difficult, but getting Purna from basically 0 up to the standard you need is not easy.

There's also new guns to play with. The shotgun selection is so much better, in the first game they were very weak, but here they've been buffed and deal great damage. There's some new melees and the game adds a lot more explosive tools to play with. Another great change with this is that traders now have a specific set of gear. One trader will sell throwing weapons, but another will sell heavy weapons. It's a great change and makes finding new weapons for your characters so much easier. 

Now, this game is fun, but the starting area is a real poor start. First off, starting with all your inventory taken away with no notice that it will happen when you carry over progression is not a good beginning. Second, doing it again at the start right when you get some cool weapons is really scummy. Third, the drowner zombies. These guys are such a pain to deal with. This game adds a travel by boat since there's flooding. And in the water, the drowner zombies sprint towards you. Not when you get close to them, if they are within 20 feet of you and you are just in the boat, they sprint towards you. They latch onto your boat and if they climb on, won't stop attacking you. When you stop controlling the boat, your character gets off the boat, which wastes even more of your time. If you decide to travel by foot in the water, they don't care unless you get right on top of them. You can get them off by speeding up with the boat, but the game doesn't tell you boats have a speed up ability, and no other vehicle has this, so you probably won't know about it first time playing. On top of that, even if you escape them latching onto your boat, since they still sprint, they will catch up to where you stop, so you still have to deal with them. Plus, later on the drowner's rules change. When you reach a new area, there's still flooding and you only travel by foot. This time, they will wake up even if you are farther away in the water. But sometimes they still don't wake up unless you are on top of them. So unless you want to check every body that hasn't woken up, you are going to have to hope they don't so you can move forward.

Now, the first area does have a great new mode that happens at scripted points. A defense mode with a horde of zombies coming to attack your position. You don't fight alone, the traders and other story characters fight alongside you. If you play single player, the other playable characters are with you fighting. You can also level up their weapons, or for traders, shops. These give you new blueprints and a lot of xp, and it also makes them more effective fighters. 

The second area of the game is where things get much better. The flooded areas are in much smaller amounts and fighting zombies is more fun. By this point, the newer guns and better ones from the previous game are given by this point. And, the ammo for them is in much more abundant supply instead of being in the safe house or in small gang hideouts. So, you are able to use your guns much more freely and without as much restraint. There is also where Purna is much more fun thanks to her gun skills and the new weapon level-ups. 

So overall, while the first area can be a pain, it does add a lot of new stuff that's fun to play with. And the second area is where the game picks up and is a ton of fun. If you can get through the first location of the game, you'll definitely have a better time in the second since this where ammo is in higher supply and great new guns are introduced.

Dead Island: Riptide Definitive Edition is an excellent addition to the already acclaimed Dead Island series. This Definitive Edition includes the original Dead Island: Riptide game along with some additional content. The game is an open world zombie survival horror game, set on a tropical island. The graphics and sound are excellent and the game has a lot of intense and exciting moments. There is also a wide variety of weapons and customizations available, allowing players to personalize their characters and create their own unique playstyle. The game also has a great co-op mode, allowing players to team up and take on the zombie hordes together. Overall, Dead Island: Riptide Definitive Edition is a great game and is highly recommended for fans of the original game and zombie survival horror games in general.

I recommend this game be played multiplayer, otherwise you need quite a bit of patience. It's not a bad game, but there are a number of things that become frustrating playing solo compared to the original Dead Island.

Infected are everywhere and some points continuously spawn them as long as you are nearby making it incredibly easy to be overrun and chain hit to death. The number of zombies that throw weapons at you are substantially higher as well and even with max health talents it's instant death. Traversing the jungle via boat is also pretty rough because drowners are so frequent, which once one gets lucky enough to rip you off the boat it's a slog to kill them in water deep enough to restrict your movement. It feels like overall damage was increased as well but I can't confirm that 100% other than by saying I used far more medkits more often.

Having jumped into this after finishing Dead Island just the other day it's easy to see the core concept is still present, but this feels somehow like an entirely different experience. Faster paced and a bit more overwhelming in a sense, which is maybe due to a greater density of zombies in certain areas. I think a better fast travel system or more points could have mitigated that feeling. Still a good game for what it is.

Just finished my first whole playthrough for these two gems in anticipation of the upcoming Dead Island 2. This game is a nice continuation from the first game. I really enjoyed the story, and I gotta say, Sam B. is still the same badass he was in the first game; one of my personal favourite playable characters from the two games. Though, I feel like this game in the beginning starts off a bit bland and boring and doesn't really start to become more interesting until midway through the campaign. I'd rate this game a 7.5/10.

[h1] [b] Dead Island: Riptide [/b] [/h1]

The second entry in the [i] Dead Island [/i] game series. Not a prequel, and not quite a sequel. So is this game worth the buy? Let's get into it. 

[h1] [b] The Good [/b] [/h1]

[*] [b] The Setting [/b]
- The Dead Island game's call to fame is its beautiful setting. "Its zombies.... But on a tropical island" was probably the birthing idea for this game series. All jokes aside, Riptide stays true to its predecessor and lets you explore through the scenic island "paradise", the flooded jungles, and eventually the urban hellscape that is the city of Hederson. When optimized correctly, these can all be intriguing and visually appealing scenes.

[*] [b] The Nostalgia [/b]
- If you're playing [i] Dead Island: Riptide [/i], there a chance that you played [i] Dead Island [/i] as well. Riptide knows this and does a decent job of bringing a little joy in from the past with continued references, Easter eggs, and continuations from the previous game. Its always nice to get a little blast from the past. 

[*] [b] The Playable Characters [/b]
- Some may say that playing as the same characters through multiple games is unoriginal and lame. I disagree, for me it helps continue their story. In Riptide, you get have five options this time around. Your choices are:

Sam B - Rapper who beats things to death
Logan - Professional Football player who throws things at other things until they die
Purna - Security who shoots things to death 
Xian Mei - Receptionist and ex-military who stabs things to death
John - Australian soldier who punches and kicks things to death

- Essentially, you can carry over your save from the first Dead Island as whatever character, or choose to play as John, the new character to the story. Never a bad thing to spice it up a little

[h1] [b] The Bad  [/b] [/h1]

[*] [b] The Story [/b]
- Now... the first Dead Island didn't exactly have the [b] best [/b] story around, but it at least was original for the series (because it was the first game.... duh). Riptide, though, decided to be brave! To be bold! Brazen even! They do this by..... Having basically the same story as the first game? "No, that can't be right." *checks notes*. "They get stranded on an island deserted with zombies, check". "Then, they have to head further into the Jungle, check". "After that, they have to head through the sewers or tunnels... to get to the large city nearby... Oh". ITS LITERALLY THE SAME STORY. LIKE THE FIRST GAME ENDS, AND THEN YOU GET SENT THROUGH THE SAME EXACT THING. It's crazy man... and kind of lame.

[*] [b] The Enemies [/b] 
- Its okay to have use the same enemies from the previous games, even in zombie games. Look at Left 4 Dead. But they at least polished how they act, and added multiple new zombies. From what I could see, there was literally only one new zombie in this game. Every other enemy was just copy pasted from the first game. Speaking of copy pasting ....

[*] [b] The Graphics and Detail [/b]
- There are like... no improvements in this game. It looks entirely the same. All models (zombies, characters, weapons, etc.) are the same as the first game. This isn't a big issue to me personally, but its part of a larger problem I will address later. 

[*] [b] The weapons and Fighting [/b]
- Multiple issues here. First, there has been practically no improvement from the first game. The melee attacks are still glitchy and clanky like in the first game. Second, all the weapon upgrades and improvements are basically the same. Yeah, there's fire, shock, bleed, and poison options, but there will be like, eight of them, and they all do, and look the same. It honestly feels kind of lazy. Third, the combat does not always register. You see a katana slice through a walker, but it doesn't hit or damage them. Inconvenient for a small fight, deadly for a major one. Throwing weapons clip through the map, making you lose rare and upgraded gear because it shot through a cliff.

[*] [b] The Clipping and NavMeshing [/b]
- You get stuck on everything in this game. You'll be running down a street being chased by a butcher and 10 infected, and your foot will clip onto the edge of a small trash can, and now you've completely stopped moving and are now dead. You will clip through ledges making you fall to your death. I've even fell through the map once while walking through the jungle. 

[h1] [b] The Ugly [/b] [/h1]

[*] [b] The Preformance [/b]
- Before getting started, no it is not my internet. No it is not my brand new gaming pc. No it is not a problem on my end. Look in any forum or comment string for this game and you see it to. This game... preforms [b] HORRIBLY [/b]. The title screen is sluggish, the actual game is horribly laggy and feels like it can barely run. Its bad enough that you could even get a headache over it. I don't understand what they did wrong, as the original [i] Dead Island [/i] from years earlier, runs perfectly. Smooth as butter. This game is clanky and rough.

[*] [b] The Lack of Originality [/b]
- This game is not a sequel. It is barely different from the first game, which I believe to be vastly superior. The combat is no different. The story is no different. The setting is barely different, you just moved over a couple islands. The game just does not in any way feel like a separate entity. It honestly fails to uphold the same standards set by the first [i] Dead Island [/i]

[h1] [b] Overall  [/b] [/h1]

Dead Island: Riptide is a DLC that pretends to be a real game. It is completely unoriginal and fails to differ from its predecessor in any way, even the PLOT OF THE STORY. It fails to bring anything new or interesting to the table and doesn't excel in any form. It performs worse, looks no better, and plays significantly worse that the first game. The fact that they charged $60 dollars for this should be a crime. They should of just released this as an add-on DLC for Dead Island , charged you $30 and called it a day.  At least if they did that, me and thousands of others wouldn't feel ripped off

Disclaimer: This game IS entertaining. You will have fun playing this. Its just that its not worth the full price as there is barely anything new. Just pick it up on sale if you want to try it

Ohhh where to start on Riptide and it's odd following.....this game wanted so badly to be the sequel to smash hit "Dead Island" but it failed on epic levels.  Let's pick at the story of it....okay so you escape from the main island where you began and end up on a ship, a ship that somehow gets overrun with zombies....highly unlikely and it crashes......there you are on yet another island.  Let's not forget that on the ship you had some decent items including some good guns, but when you awaken on the island post crash your weapons mysteriously disappear as you're greeted by some random female and instantly nailed with a fetch quest for a group of people you don't know if you can trust.  

Is there any build up to the stories of the people on the island? Nope.  Just everything thrown at you all at once and don't try to use the map legend as it really doesn't have one.  If you wanted guns in the first game then play Craptide err I mean Riptide otherwise just stick with the first game because it does everything better.

A great follow-up from the base game of Dead Island, following and continuing the story that ends once again with a cliff-hanger that the player-base is waiting till this day for what comes next. But maybe soon.

The engine uses the same engine as the first game, which means same bugs and glitches, as well as same play-style for the most part, which isn't a bad thing since the combat can be quite enjoyable more often than not. The skill-tree has some improvements from the first game too [spoiler](Getting up quicker after being knocked down)[/spoiler].

Overall a good game to play-through if you enjoyed the first game and you're looking for some extra story and a new map (which often is more annoying to traverse through really). 

A great refresher game to play whilst waiting for DI2 and hoping it will be as great a game as it's predecessors.

What can I even say about this game, it feels like Techland saw what the first game did good and what it did bad and then decided to do absolutely nothing in order to make the game better!

The location in both the games is practically the same, start in a touristy area where youre kinda learning the ropes, progress through a transit area before coming over to an urban area to somewhat conclude the game. Very uninspired and basically just a copy-paste.

Characters, oh boy, the same cast, same shitty Voice acting, models look like ass even for the time. Dont even get me started on side-characters. After the 3rd male character I met I was convinced the entire island had one inhabitant that just kept changing outfits and teleporting around to fuck with me as if the entire story was one big prank and oh boy the story.

The story is laughable, Im pretty sure i prefer the first games story but seeing as I've played that one ages ago I cannot quite recall, wouldnt be surprised if they copied that aspect of it too and just literally made Dead Island 1.15.
Even if we disregard the entire copy aspect of it the story is still laughably terrible, im pretty sure if you asked a classroom of prepubescent teens to each write their own zombie ridden world one of them would write a better one than this. 
One positive that came from the fiasco that this game was I guess is Dying Light. 
I dont think the studio would've survived another Dead Island. So in a way thank the heavens for the DI2 delays back in the day.

[h1]Overview[/h1]
This game is one of the most wanted play in my Highschool era. But at the time i dont have miney to buy any steam games. But now i have so i bought it. Just realised DI Riptide is continuity of Dead Island. So damn i must buy another one. But judging with my current standard of games. This is my review:

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
+ Graphics is good for its time.
+ Story is linear but understandable
+ World is rich enough than original Dead Island
+ Lots of customization, some is better than original DI
+ Really fun with friends

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
- Story too short. Especially for its price, it feels like small DLC/expansion pack than new game.
- Its really boring to Play alone. Must play with friends..
- Playing alone also harder. Because every characters has unique traits, its kinda hard to maximize all stats when you needed.
- Idk the VA and Music kinda terrible for me. Music i replace it with my Spotify. VA makes certain scene forgetable.
- After I played the 1st game, this game actually much more smaller in city size. Making me felt MORE about this game should be a DLC than sequels/newer game.
[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
The conclusion is this game is a fun multiplayer zombie game, well made with few glitches, and had few upgrades than original DI game. But as a new game, this should be a DLC...
good

This is probably one of the most poorly programmed games I have ever played in my entire life. How this game has so many positive reviews is a mystery to rival the vanishing of the Roanoke colony. I only paid $4.00 for this game and I still feel like I got ripped off. Had I paid full price and Steam refused to give me a refund my next call would be to my lawyer to pursue civil litigation (yes I would be that petty). I played this game for 7+ hours before I finally could not take it anymore. Here is the gist of it: half of all melee attacks just clip right through enemies to the point that anything but weapons with a large attack radius (like pickaxes and shovels) are completely useless, the jump attack puts you into a frozen animation about 50% of the time (leaving you open to attack), enemies (especially thugs) will somehow hit you despite being far out of grabbing range, and "infected" cannot be killed with a vehicle as they just clip right over the top of your car. But worst of all is the motorboat. About half of the vehicle travel in the game is done using a new motorboat that is used to traverse the rivers and flooded areas (which make up a significant portion of the map). The water is absolutely crawling with zombies, far too many to avoid. Every zombie will immediately clip under the boat which will cause it to become stuck which basically means death as you cannot run through water, but the zombies can (WTF????). Motorboat travel is virtually impossible in this game, and if not impossible then it is so ungodly frustrating that the developers should be paying the players to put up with it. DO NOT BUY THIS GAME EVEN IF IT IS ON SALE! IT IS NOT WORTH PLAYING EVEN IF THE GAME IS OFFERED FOR FREE! Play the first Dead Island, and if you already have then move onto a different game series. Perhaps the original Dead Island Riptide has better performance, though after playing this one I do not think I have the courage to buy it after wasting my money on this one. Yes, it is THAT bad.
Boy do I love smashing zombies in this [strike] DLC [/strike] SEQUEL

I'll be quite honest, I went into this game knowing that it had a reputation for being pretty bad, but I had bought it in a bundle with Dead Island for $5 and decided to download it one day after finishing Dead Island. What followed was a week of pain and suffering that became unbearable after just a few hours and I had to put it down for a couple days before limping over the finish line.

I went in wanting to fully experience game, getting all the collectibles, all quests, yadda yadda yadda. However after a multitude of crashes, something that only happened once on Dead Island, even for as janky as it is, should've been the biggest warning. Regardless, I pressed on, and what I found was quest after quest after quest of getting someone's crap from the other side of the damn map and bringing it back to them and it was just so unbelievably tedious that by the time I got to the second area I gave up on doing any of the side quests or even getting the collectibles and just rushed through the story, but even that was a slog.

In the story you are beset by incompetent survivors who find it their best idea to take the absolute piss out of the immune people because....... reasons? They say it's because they're really aggressive and highly agitated, but hell, when you keep being a pissant and keep giving them shit for.... being aggressive towards zombies? it get's really annoying. By the end I didn't give a single damn about any of these survivors, whether they lived or died horribly, just the purest distillation of apathy. 

And finally we come to the bugs. Oh dear God, the bugs. I don't know how many times I had to restart that stupid, idiotic, retarded cinema holdout because Infected kept spawning into the walls or places where I couldn't kill them. There's also the laser zombies that every knows about, those are real fun. Quest dialogue just... not happening. Sound cutting out. Quests being uncompletable for unknown reasons. The map marker having a mind of it's own, you get the idea. The game is busted and is probably held together by hope and a very thin lining of glue.

And for the last section, the bosses. The really bad, not-fun-at-all bosses. I've never really wanted to fight jacked-up versions of enemies and this game just took that idea and ran with it, and boy, are they not fun. Playing as Sam B, I found the only real reliable way to kill the bosses was have full Fury and hope to Christ you could out heal their damage or stun lock them. If they had multiple Infected spawn in the fight, guess what, you're boned. You will get swarmed and die so fast it isn't funny. I don't ever remember dying once in Dead Island while having Fury active, but in Riptide it was constant; everything just chunks your healthbar even if you build into tankiness, you don't feel any stronger. However, there is one light in this tunnel and that is the Harlow fight. Harlow is a complete joke as Sam B. You activate Fury, bum rush her, and stun lock her into oblivion, then you use the McGuffin and get infinite Fury and  you just stun lock into a corner until the game tells you to stop. The fight is still bad, don't get me wrong; after punching her for a solid 30 seconds the sound just cut out except for her grunts of pain, even the chainsaw was gone. But yeah, you just punch Harlow for about 3 minutes straight then you walk a somehow confusing route to the boat (Seriously Deep Silver, why make the route overly complicated and not just a straight to the dock?), watch the one guy you've wanted to kill the whole game die, sail off, and get a very pedestrian ending that unfortunately looks like it's gonna be canon considering Dead Island 2.

And with all that, I uninstalled and will never be finishing this game, plain and simple. It's just bad.

Dead Island: Riptide is an unwanted extension of your relaxing vacation on a tropical island. I hope you’ve packed enough sunscreen, baseball bats, machetes and Molotov cocktails in the first game, because you will need plenty of them again!

Riptide picks up immediately where the previous game ended. You can even import your character and your progress from the previous game, but this is something you need to think through first, as weapons and blueprints are NOT carried over, meaning you will be immediately pitched against high level enemies, while you try to defend yourself with a low level broomstick, for example. The game itself is no different from its predecessor. If you expect better graphics, a lot of improved gameplay or less bugs and glitches, you will be disappointed. On the other hand, if you really enjoyed [url=https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198067384854/recommended/383150/]Dead Island[/url], you will have no problem jumping right in and enjoy this one as well.

Despite being pretty much the same, the sequel does have a few new things to offer. The first thing it does is introduce a fifth and new playable character to you, the sympathetic John Morgan. Once again, all characters have their own three unique skill trees that you can use to improve your character’s fighting abilities and chances of survival. Another cool thing is Hub Defense, in which you and some other survivors have to defend your sanctuary against a horde of undead. Next to cars you now also have boats. Those are more of a necessity than a commodity, since going for a casual swim isn’t really recommend anymore post-zombie apocalypse. Gun enthusiasts will also be happy to know that guns are more prevalent in this game than in the previous, which relied much more on melee combat. There are more new features, but I’ll let you figure that out yourself.

The soundtrack is provided again by Paweł Błaszczak, who does another great job in creating a grim and despairing atmosphere but - when it’s time for a breather - also knows how to calm you down.

Like [url=https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198067384854/recommended/383150/]Dead Island[/url], despite being the Definitive Edition and including all the DLC, it also has its flaws. If you are a forgiving player like me and have a vivid imagination, then you will have a blast. As long as you can complete it and it isn’t too game-breaking, it personally doesn’t bother me that much. Life isn’t perfect and neither are video games. As far as I’m concerned, [url=https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198067384854/recommended/383150/]Dead Island[/url] and Dead Island: Riptide are still two of the best zombie games ever made.

This game is like an abusive relationship.

It's going all well at first. But after a while it all goes to shit and it makes you feel like human garbage. And you can't escape it or even attempt to leave (because it runs at 2 fps and the menu select is dookie).

I had such fond memories of Dead Island - I'd originally bought that game not realizing it was FPS (the only other FPS I'd played in those days was Portal), and was irritated at first expecting more of like a 3rd person shooter based on the trailer (dumb, I know).   That irritation quickly faded as I got used to the controls and started just melting into the story.   By the time I was running all of the church missions, I was hooked.  Going back and forth between the various areas also made the world feel alive... the game was phenomenal.

This one? Not so much.

When you finish in an area, you're done... you just go from one to the next.  You CAN go back, but there's no need to.  The mission variety was also pretty minimal... mostly fetch quests buffering the main story.  As for the emotional heart-strings of the original...?  There is ONE quest where you are tasked with helping a dude find his wife, and there are maybe two moments of that quest where it comes kind of close to the feels of the original Dead Island...but that's it.    The world of the original Dead Island was alive.  The world of Riptide?  Not so much.

I'm not recommending it, but the only people who might want to play Riptide are people who JUST played DI the first time, and want to see the story through till the end.  Seriously though, you're probbably better off just reading the Wikipedia page for the story, and moving on to dying light or Dead Island 2.

Honestly this game is just dead island but worse and that kind of sucks. I love the casebook thing that details the zombies and the inclusion of your chosen player character having way more to say and the voice acting being better overall. Hearing Sam B always made me happy. That's about the only change i like though unfortunately. The new combat moves are extremely janky (ofcourse it is its dead island) and often made me feel disappointed when i used them and would prefer if they were just not even here as they don't really add much to the game as they are. The plot is about as disappointing as the first game with missions being mostly fetch quest like, the difference being that riptides world is a slog to explore. The boat controls terribly and will be stopped if a single zombie gets in front of it which totally kills the flow. The cars should have just been left out the game as every road is blocked with some foliage or water making them useless to exist in this map. The new zombie types are not very creative and feel like remodels of existing zombies, and they barely ever show up anywhere anyway. This game is even less polished than dead island and some areas are just missing details so obvious that it baffles me how nobody bothered to correct it. The combat isn't anymore difficult but zombies feel more spongy than before and spawn in even bigger hoards, which mostly just leads to you being trapped in a corner fending off against a ton of tanky enemies while you sit there helpless. This game is honestly just mediocre and i'd give it a mixed review if i could, but since i cannot i lean more towards the negative with riptide as opposed to how i feel about dead island where i felt more on the positive side.

Dead Island: Riptide is one of the games I’ve ever played.  I pressed the move keys and watched as my inputs were matched on screen.  I clicked my mouse at various things and objects.  I progressed, imputed, and even upgraded.  I most certainly played a video game.  And that’s all there is.

I could dig into Dead Island: Riptide.  I could go over the slow pacing both in story and movement, the long and sluggish animations, the zombies spawning right in front of me, instant respawning with little to no penalties, the terrible writing and voice acting, the confusing themes, and so on and so forth.  I could do all of that.

But why bother?  It doesn’t take much for me to go on a tirade on even the most basic of games.  How they are hollow cash grabs or lacking in artistic integrity or missing the importance of a cohesive theme and good narrative.  I’ve done it for worse games, I’ve given games like Homefront and Wildlands a fair shake, why should Dead Island be any different?

Thing is those games all invoked some sort of emotion in me.  Almost all negative emotions, but emotions nonetheless.  Anger, sadness, and hopelessness from merely playing them.  Dead Island doesn’t do any of this, it just sort of exists.  It is just competent enough, that’s really a good way to describe the whole game, it’s just competent enough.

The writing is below average but it’s passable.  The characters are boring and stale but not incompetant or irrational.  The gameplay is clunky and slow but it works well enough.  Its themes are generic and predictable but not unwarranted.  It’s all just fine, it works.

It is a video game.

We don’t even have the what ifs to fall back on.  The woes of what could have been and the deep dive of how it could have been saved, because we already have it.  It’s called Dying Light.  They took Dead Island and added a better movement system, smoother animations, and a more cohesive story.  Dying Light still shares many of Dead Island’s flaws, hell it shares a lot of assets too, but Dying Lights focused changes to the formula elevate the gameplay loop and the game follows.  It still has a hollow story, mixed themes and so forth.  But it has an identity all of its own.  While Dead Island sort of just wallows in its own mediocrity.

So we have the upgrade.  We have seen what happens when the gameplay is given the attention it deserves and doesn’t just widely chase after trends.  So where does that leave Dead Island?  It seems to have been made completely redundant.

There is literally no reason to come play this game anymore.  Dying Light doesn’t have anything to do with Dead Island lore or storywise.  And I guarantee there is nothing Dead Island does better than Dying Light in any capacity.  

If Dead Island was a bad game that everyone hated then maybe it would at least have something to latch onto.  It could act as some sort of warning or it could be a demonstration of the duality of art or something.

What’s even the point?  Is it even art anymore?  If it’s not then it would have something to say, being a sort of post-modern piece.  But if it is it has nothing to say and nothing to give.  A nothing piece of art.  This in and of itself would warrant some kind of discussion.  Some sort of acknowledgment.

But it doesn’t.  Because it’s fine.  Just, fine.

Cons: 
1. Poor Map design, especially the first area that made me actively wanna skip quests because of the swamps.
2. It's either you one shot or get one shot.
3. Horrible money economy + complete lack of loot
4. Terrible enemy balance, way too many of them in certain areas + the special infected are scarce, in fact a decent chunk are only discover-able in the very end.
5. Final boss was difficult because of how hard i was laughing at the shitty cutscenes in between phases. They didn't even bother making the boss look different each phase, only made 'em slightly bigger.
6. Buggy as hell, like quests not progressing, explosives not damaging enemies or the random echo noise you hear for no reason just about everywhere.
7. When you finish a side quest step it auto tracks a main quest instead of moving on to the next step of the side quest
8. The 'find it yourself through the green circle that's in the map' quests got annoying.
9. Special infected went from too squishy to bullet sponges that annihilate you in a few smacks. 


1. Defense quests were nice.
2. Generous XP that really helped flesh out character building.
3. AOE attack weapon mods.

This re-release of the 'Dead Island' sequel-spansion is, like its predecessor, a series of trade-offs on PC...
While getting a multiplayer game going is now a breeze, the game is a port from the consoles -- so the physics, combat, performance, visuals, and other factors are definitely below-par.

What you get is a survival/combat, open world, story experience in the vein of Lucio Fulci or Dario Argento; complete with their inherent cheapness.  It is better optimized than the first remastered title, and you get the option of playing a new & unique 5th character, or even porting your previous character from the first 'Definitive' title.

Only really worth it on sale, due to the handicapping of combat (the game is locked on 'digital') -- if you have a friend or 3 available, it does offer a meaningful co-op campaign experience.
Please note, that you do have to finish a single-player prologue before co-op is unlocked.

I am a 54 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game.

This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you were supposed to do. I asked my son for help and he hosted a game for me to join.

I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

Enjoyed the first game, but this unacceptable. Avoid this game if you value your time.

Dead Island & Dead Island Riptide as themselves provoke such a loving nostalgia for me, as they're a major contributing factor that fueled my love for apocalyptic and dystopian games involving infectious plagues. I've completed the 1st & 2nd game as every character through the PlayStation & XBox 360 as a teen & now as an adult I am planning to complete the 1st & 2nd game as every character for a 3rd (possibly 4th) time.

although it's got its bugs, issues, and lots of generic similarities to the 1st game, I love playing. I love the meme factor of dying without rhyme or reason, or panicking "he's got a knife!!" knowing if it's thrown at me & hits I'm 1 shot. sometimes it's genuinely frustrating, but I get over it rather quickly. imo losing money isn't an automatic death sentence, it's rather simple to get nice weaponry and resources with or without money as the environment is often bustling with items to collect. I love the lore behind Dead Island & Dead Island Riptide, the characters, the dumbassery involved & everything.. something I would've liked for Dying Light & Dying Light 2 is the ability to activate "fury" like you're able to via Dead Island, that is probably one of the only things I wish they would've kept! besides getting to take a delicious, singular bite out of an apple you discovered right next to a dead guy's rotting, infected corpse & helping yourself to a refreshing energy drink a zombie very likely sh@t in. I love Techland & their games. always. I recommend if you're not easily butthurt after dying to unknown causes!

Against to what publisher and devs say, this is not a stand-alone DLC - this is Dead Island 2.

The game has a similar plot length as the first one and has the same price. It is advertised as DLC because Riptide doesn't have any improvement apart for a few details. They knew they'd get lots of negative critics for selling a new game with same bugs, on the same unimproved engine.

I value in games the stories they’re telling and again as in the first DI, we’ve got a fail here. There is an unused potential for a great screenplay, but instead we are given not very amusing tasks with an intriguing ending. One good idea is enough for a road RPG game, but not enough for continuous story.

New game, old bugs:
– The game has a problem with zombie-zombie collisions. Don’t be surprised when you will be fighting a big special infected and suddenly you get hit by an another regular one running through it like a ghost through a wall. It can be really annoying in close quarters when you think you can fight one zombie coming out of the door, but two others think the door is not blocked and merge on each other;
- Zombies sometimes are having problem with locating the player and chase him in opposite direction;
- Zombies spawns in front of you, especially often when you’re steering a boat.
- If you have a higher ground and you throw a molly onto your enemies, you still take damage if the fire is directly underneath you (no matter how high you are above it);
- Not working map marker – you can mark a waypoint on your map, but it only shows you directions when you’re 50 meters away, meaning you don’t need it anymore. Quest markers are working properly.
- Annoying constant talks of NPCs when you're at the camps. Annoying is not the fact that they always talk every single time you pass them, but the fact they're keep on talking when you take new quests and they won’t stop until they finish their lines. This was especially buggering at the hospital where you can find a girl that has long, slow-going lines. Everything would be fine if the game could turn their voices down a little.
- Our playable characters can talk even if they die.

A new attack has been added to the game, but sadly it’s still a beta version of the idea. So, you have to press ‘F’ when you are on a higher ground than the enemy to make your character jump-kick on them and do them with one hit. It’s useless if you have more zombies, because after the attack you cannot move for 3 seconds – enough to get slaughtered. It happened to me many times I didn’t hit anything but landed next to the zombie, even though I didn’t have any fence or anything in front of me. Another time I was overrun so I used the ladder to get myself into safety and started eating snacks, but because it’s the same button instead of grabbing an apple Xian jumped back to the horde. This skill should be removed.

The game was created for co-op, but the animations are still crippled. Our characters jump like they’d swallow a broomstick – with legs in move but standstill torso. Well, what are we talking about – it’s 2013 and they still used separate head/torso elements so they were forced to use the old trick with covering the visible line with necklaces/beads/scarves/others

I am aware this "review" is just pointing out the disadvantages, but I didn't have much fun playing for the second time the same game. You can now reach lvl 70, but the skills are basically the same. If the game would be half price the base game, I'd consider giving it a recommendation.
