Dead Island Definitive Edition is a disgrace to the Dead Island name.

While the game is upgraded with new character abilities - that's as far as the positive aspects go. The entire game takes place in a drab and boring jungle full of water, keeping your walking speed at a snail's pace. There are boats, but they're a pain to use.

I'm not sure why the steam reviews are mostly positive - I've never met a single Dead Island player that enjoyed this sequel. 

Speak to ANY Dead Island player - none of them will have much positive to say about this sequel.

Dead Island Riptide is a bizarre sequel/standalone expansion to the first title. You play again as the previous survivors with no personalities with a new additional character that likes to punch things. The game takes you to a new island that is much more rural than Banoi with most of the game playing like an even worse designed jungle level from the first with some poorly made flooded sections for max frustration. The weapons have been rebalanced so there is less emphasis on firearms with ammo being hard to get until late game and even then they are not worth using. 

The game fundamentally plays the same, frustrating BS deaths, flailing your weapon around like an idiot trying to hit zombies with mixed success, but with the addition of siege levels where you defend an area from a horde. It is actually a fun new mode that does not happen enough to get annoying. 

Dead Island Riptide is the same masochistic crap fest the first game was but even worse. If you thought the first game was fun and you feel like you want to frustratingly die over and over again and enjoy it then give it a try when it is on sale.

I guess I understand why people hated this game. About 70% of the game was recycled assets from the first game and the improvements are very minor. The game is slightly shorter to finish even after doing all the sidequests and playing with friends. I did like that they added more zombies and made the story slightly more interesting, but that is short lived after one of the worst final boss fights I ever had. The biggest improvements in this game is guns being actually useful and you don't fight many human enemies. The best way to look at this game is consider it as an expansion of the original while having the ability to import any of your characters from it too. If you want more Dead Island then buy this on sale, but don't expect anything game changing.

It is an amazing game in my opinion. I only can't recommend it because of how irritating and un-fun a solo play through is. I loved playing it on 360 and I'm having tons of fun on PC, but the game is just too damn hard with all the new glitches in this version of the game. The first Dead Island is far more playable, this felt like a rushed DLC. The amount of glitches you experience in combat makes the game feel unplayable once you get 60% through. The city segments have zombies EVERYWHERE. When you spawn after dying, you'll be thrown into the middle of MORE ZOMBIES who often will trap you in the corner you spawned in and kill you again. If there are too many, they'll attack at odd intervals and interrupt any attempts at defending yourself. I've been trying to get the Super-Fish for about an hour and I can't figure out how to stop getting spawn killed, I was taking damage while my character was still spawning in, I could not even move and by the time i could, it was 1 hit until i died again. This game will test you, HARD. You gotta have nerves of steel to get through the wall clipping and glitchy combat. If you can, this game is definitely one you should consider playing. When I first heard this game came out I had a bad feeling that this would be just as bad or even worse than the original. Well, I was right, it's even worse.

TL;DR There are even less redeeming qualities than the original game. Voice acting, cutscenes, gameplay, and level design are all rough. This was a cash grab copy-paste of the original but everything is worse.

[b][u]STORY[/u][/b]
You escaped the island of Banoi in the last game, now you crashed ship on another island you have to make your way off of.

[b][u]GAMEPLAY[/u][/b]
The gameplay here is the same but worse from the previous game. It is copy-pasted, but with all bugs and trash mechanics still intact. The main quests are broken, and the island is so difficult to navigate around without getting PO'd. Here is what I had to say about the last one:

  "[i]The gameplay for Dead Island is buggy, annoying, and so stale that the 4-year-old piece of popcorn under your couch tastes fresher in comparison... Quests are ridiculously boring because you are fetching something 98% of the time.

  You are going to quickly realize how horribly executed every mechanic in this game is. Fast stamina depletion extend playtime WAY too much... Weapons purposely break after 20-30 swings. Repairing your busted up weapons requires [b]money[/b] instead of resources. You will lose all of your money you just earned from missions and exploration.

  ...Skill tree design is actual trash and barely helpful for your character. Also, don't get me started on the gunplay. All I will say is the guns in this game are pellet guns with inferior ammo reserves (I think your max ammo capacity is 3-clips worth - THATS IT).

  The zombies can be so frustrating. Normal zombies chucking weapons like boat paddles at you is probably the most infuriating thing in the game. The damage stats on the weapons they throw are extremely low, yet they knock you down and take 75% of your health in one hit. "Thugs" and "Tanks" knock you down and deplete your health drastically with every hit. You will find yourself avoiding them when you can rather than taking them down.[/i]"

[b][u]SOUND[/u][/b]
This game kept the same sound effects and music from the original. The voice acting is quite possibly far worse than the first, which I didn't know was possible. The only decent voice acting is once again done by Phil LaMarr (Sam B).

[b][u]GRAPHICS/VISUALS[/u][/b]
The setting here is awful. The beach area was the only enjoyable setting from the first Dead Island, while the jungle section was horrible to trudge through. The jungle setting is the majority of this game and it is worse than before.

[b][u]OVERALL[/u][/b]
Even less enjoyable than the original Dead Island. Again, the only fun part of this is playing it and making fun of it with friends. We got so infuriated with this one we quit after 2 hours. I will not be returning to this one either.

[b]Dead Island: Riptide Definitive Edition = 2/10[/b]

"Definitive Edition" is like "Remastered"

"Polish a turd it is still a turd" comes to mind. All flash and no substance. 

Took stuff out, put some things in, driving still sucks, running and walking around is janky as. Not very keyboard friendly, feels like a console port. Having to press buttons multiple times when in other games I only need one or 2 different button presses to get to the quest I want or change a weapon etc etc. Even on consoles it is easy to get through the menus to switch weapons but this is constantly stressful. 

Lacks any emotional response from me when every other game manages to get some sort of response like feeling sorry for the characters. I just want to kill everyone and put them out of their misery this game is so depressing. Other depressing games I want to save people even if they die in the end scenes etc but this is like...nope...nuke em all let God sort them out. 

No difficulty sliders. Forced to do arbitrary side quests to upgrade your "friends" and helpers so they have a sliver of hope of surviving nonsense tower defence style fight scenes. Feel like I'm forced to play the original just to learn the game and enemy types, throws MORE enemy types in the 2nd game. Feels like artificial difficulty increase for the sake of it without even testing if anyone wants it. 

TLDR - Game was exciting in the first game, got bloated like a floater in the second and became a huge chore in making sure everyone has the best stuff at all times to survive. Looks really pretty on the surface but dig deeper and it's like trying to hold your intestines in while Zombies are literally eating them.

It's not required to have played Dead Island before this one in terms of the story as it starts with a lore recap. The game though will expect you know how to deal with special zombies (e.g. you won't get a tutorial showing that Suiciders explode when close to you or how to deal with Rams).

Never played the original release.
Riptide seems to have had smaller budget and/or less time for development. The game is more traditional open world with only 2 maps, but much more stuff to do in them. The jungle is a much more interesting version of the bases game's jungle, and Henderson is... a much more interesting version of Moresby, especially visually. Sprinkled throughout the maps are small instanced, what I like to call, challenge rooms. They are full of zombies and a boss. Unleashing a fully maxed out Fury on them is recommended, repetitive... but also tons of fun, each and every time you do it.
Seems to be less serious that the original. It shows even in the main theme being more... funky I would say. There's also the quest for the horror director who, of course, does not care about his crew and just wants to finish shooting his movie.
The player characters are much more vocal this time, instead of going just "uh huh", "yes", "of course", when accepting quests, they actually talk with people.
Gameplay wise the import function and additional levels allow you to create a truly overpowered character, full power fantasy. However, since this occurs over the course of two games, I think it's perfectly fine.
Several new mechanics have been added, unfortunately most of them are very janky. The Charge skill sometimes pulverizes an enemy, other times it leaves it with a sliver of health, and there are times where it misses completely and you are barreling down a cliff. The Jump Attack often either misses or gets you stuck, and the "get-off-my-boat" QTE makes the zombies fly away as if hit by a Falcon Punch. This really could have been ironed out in this remaster.
There are also problems with sound, where it cuts off. It happens with stationary miniguns, mine explosions, and Fury for some characters. I've tried numerous solutions, but none worked.
There's a village in the game where tons of assets are misaligned. We are speaking about dozens of trash cans clipping into buildings, fruit floating, crates sinking into ground. There is so much of it, it is literally impossible to miss just by playing the game normally. It's embarrassing. Since I have not played the original version, I wonder whether it's the Definitive Edition's fault.

Overall, I had more fun with Riptide than with the base game, despite all of the jank and technical issues. It seems to be focused more on pure fun in great environments/locations.

I played both this and the original back in the day. Knowing what those were all about, I can say that the "Definitive Edition" is without a doubt the inferior version of this already-flawed series. Both main games are buggy, seem to have some minor content bits cut out, and have fixed none of the long-standing issues with this franchise.

The original [i]Dead Island: Riptide[/i] was virtually a carbon-copy of the original, but it did have some technical optimizations that made it more playable. This "improved" version looks worse than the original version. Like with the rest of this edition, it looks like someone smeared Vaseline all over the screen. The games look so dated and second-rate compared to other remasters out there.

[i]Dead Island: Riptide[/i] did have a few minor quality of life improvements over the original. However, despite that, its main flaws still remained the same. The biggest issues with this game, like with the original [i]Dead Island[/i], are in the movement and combat systems. They are clunky, slow, unpolished, and buggy. Aiming and shooting guns is weird and not fun. The hitboxes and detection stinks. Melee weapons break far too easily and guns run out of ammo too quickly. The stamina system is annoying as well. To make matters even worse, melee combat is hindered by the cluggy, slow movement speed of your character that makes dodging or avoiding the powerful zombie attacks virtually impossible, which is problematic considering that you can't take much damage before going down. It's especially an issue when you're facing larger hordes or special zombies in tight, enclosed areas.

The story supposedly picks up right where the original [i]Dead Island[/i] left off, but it mostly ends up going in its own direction real quick, which is a drag because the directions that this game takes are god-awful. The new characters feel like clones of the ones from the original and Palanai isn't too different than Banoi in terms of feel. The story in this game essentially contradicts a lot of what you know from the last game (e.g. the virus still lives within you in dormancy even though the head scientist in the last game clearly stated that it died when you got exposed to it) and it goes on a dumb tangent about roentgens, mutagens, and whatnot - all of which I guess are intended to justify the utter crapshow of an ending it all culminates in (hint: all of your work and frustration across these two games may very well be for absolutely nothing).

Unfortunately, the "Definitive Edition" is the only version for sale on Steam anymore, which is kind of a shame, as the Definitive Edition isn't the superior version. It brings its own issues to the table in a franchise that's perhaps best known for its issues to begin with. If you really want it, get it on sale; otherwise, I'd recommend passing it up until then.

[i]Dead Island: Riptide[/i] is more of the same if you liked the original game. You can even port in your character profile(s) from the first game, which will give you a significant leg-up going in. Killing zombies is fun when the game's systems work as intended, but it doesn't take much for them to fail you. There are a few new zombie types thrown into the mix, but they don't really add much (if any) value to the overall game. Questing is the same as in the original game and its just as repetitive and tedious. Ultimately, it all gets old before long.

[b]Final Score:[/b] 4/10

It's more of the same that one expects coming off the first [i]Dead Island[/i] game, but it soon gets old and the long-standing issues with this franchise will soon leave your hair thinner than the zombies in the game.

Dead Island: Riptide Definitive Edition is a remaster of Dead Island: Riptide. It looks and plays the same as the previous DI games, an open-world, zombie action survival game. Due to the naming of the title, many people assume Riptide is another version of Dead Island, but it's not, it's actually a sequel which takes place almost directly after the ending of the main game. You can even import your character, retaining your level and skills, but not inventory. There's a new character, but if you wanna try him out you must start from level 1.

In Riptide you explore a whole new area, but it continues the "vacation island" theme. In my opinion, the areas of this game looks better and feels more coherent compared to the areas in the first game, although there's no hotel level which for me is the most memorable part. This game is also shorter, about 2/3 or even half of the length DI, which is actually preferable since DI kinda overstays its welcome. Sadly both games share a poorly-done finale, where you must fight through hordes of zombies inside a linear, claustrophobic building to get to the escape vehicle. There's also less human enemies here, which is ironically my favorite fights in the main game.

One major improvement about this game is how it treats the characters. Playable characters have more personalities, like each of them have unique dialogue when talking to characters rather than some generic variations of "yes/no". The non-chosen characters also hang around the other survivors instead of not appearing at all, and you can do some item collecting quests for them to improve their power while fighting in base defense missions. Side characters are also more fleshed-out, although sadly there's not enough character models so many side and minor characters look similar.

The problems I have with this game is mostly the same with the first one: very poor optimization, hardy zombies + fragile weapons, far away fast travel spots, and too many sidequests are fetch quests. But the improvements are also great, I feel more attached to the characters due to them having more personalities and the maps are not as large so travelling around isn't very tedious. Although sadly both this game and the original version doesn't have any story DLC, it only has some exclusive weapons and a barely-noticeable costume change.

Personally, I think Dead Island: Riptide is the better game compared to Dead Island, due to more likable characters, better level design and setting, more enemy variations, and a more coherent story. But even with the story recap at the beginning, you should still play the first one. If you like open-world action games and/or zombie games, give the Dead Island franchise a try. Even if you dislike the first game, it gets better here.

I don't know where to start... 

*disclaimer* : This review is from a single player perspective.

Firstly let me emphasize that the entire game reuses assets from the first one. Everything from the combat quality (or lack of) to the clunky movement, driving, most weapons and so on. They've made no effort to enhance the game past the last engine. 

Secondly, they dug the hole even deeper when it comes to everything done wrong in the first game. to clarify,almost all the quests in my almost 8 hours of playtime have been "fetch" quests, while the entire group of 10+ survivors rely completely upon you to do all of their dirty work while they trash talk you in the process. Furthermore, the terrain is even trickier to navigate, with many swamps where you can only walk slowly while zombies run at full speed, and narrow roads, making it very annoying to get from one place to another. 

To conclude, in my opinion they have lost the plot with this one. The first game, despite the downsides, had a certain charm to it which this game lacks completely. It almost seems like they were trying to milk every last penny in their original asset pack and put together this mess to cash it in. A 5/10 at best.

After completing the original Dead Island, I was craving more of of the zombie bashing surviving genre. Luckily, for me, Techland produced Dead Island Riptide which is meant to be a sequel to the original Dead Island. 

Story:

This game can be thought of more like a massive expansion or DLC for the original games as you still have the same playable characters (in addition to an extra one). Furthermore, you can import a character you used in the original Dead Island where you will retain the same level and perks you chose on the skill tree. The game quite literally picks up from where the last one ended, except this time you have a brand new Island to explore consisting of a huge jungle and city. There maybe less maps than the original game, but these two maps are pretty big in themselves. The story still focuses on the idea of finding the cause of this outbreak and a vaccine to stop it. I won't spoil the ending, but I liked the twist at the end and how this linked into the gameplay mechanic of 'fury' established in the previous games. 

Gameplay:

One thing that struck me in this game was how the level system had been revamped! There are a few new perks to collect such as 'group fury' where you can deal additional damage to zombies if you activate 'fury' whilst fighting with your group in the solo campaign. There is a lot more emphasis on 'holding out' against a hoard of zombies to protect your base in this game as well as the traditional 'going out' and doing errands as well. Another thing that is different is that you can specialise in a certain weapon such as throwing knifes, blunt weapons, fire weapons etc. So the more you use, say, throwing knifes, the more you will level that up and the more benefits your will get out of it such as reduced stamina usage. 

Other than that the game plays like before, with a few extra types of zombies that pose a threat to the player. I started this game at level 35 with Sam B (imported from Dead Island) and finished him on level 65 as there is level scaling where the zombies level up with you so they are always posing a threat to the player. 

Overall, I really loved the Dead Island series. I can't wait for Dead Island 2 to be released sometime in the future (hopefully, Deep Silver release Dead island 2 on Steam and not just keep it on one platform as an exclusive like they are doing with some of their other games). For now, I will just need to content myself with Techland's Dying Light!

Dead Island Riptide is a buggy, unfinished mess of a game that doesn’t build upon the previous game like a sequel traditionally does, but rather completely copies the original game. Riptide takes place after the events of the original Dead Island, where immediately after being rescued you crash onto another island that is very identical to the first one and go through a story that is forgettable and uninteresting. You play as the original 4 characters from the first game and a fifth new one who specializes in fighting with his bare hands and not a weapon which sounds like it could be cool, however I constantly kept finding weapons as a better source of damage so most of his skills were pointless. The main 4 characters have exactly the same skill trees as the last game aside from a couple additional skills which really adds to my thought of huge parts of the game being copy and pasted. Even the character models for the NPCs look just like characters from Dead Island aside from maybe a different colored shirt.
So even though most of the game is copy and pasted from the original they did add a couple new features. The biggest selling point was that you could perform tasks to improve the characters at your camp so that when you need to fight off hordes of zombies, they’ll be stronger and better equipt. However, this only ever comes up like two or three times and there really isn’t much of a difference in their abilities during these fights since you’ll end up doing most of the work anyway. Aside from that they also added boats as a vehicle since the new island is mostly flooded, but they basically handle like the cars do and honestly having a slightly different vehicle as a reason to buy the sequel is not a good selling point.
Where Dead Island Riptide falls apart the most for me is the combat and the bugs. The combat is somehow more broken than it was in the original game. There are several cheap deaths in the game where if a zombie is holding an item and threw it at me, I died instantly with no way to react. The special and bosses are also annoying because they used the lazy dev method of “take a regular enemy and give them a bunch of health”, except it’s one step further where minutes would pass by of me hitting the same enemy over and over again. It never felt satisfying to take down these difficult enemies, every time I saw them and knew I needed to fight it just felt like an absolute chore. There are also major bugs in spawning where several groups of zombies will spawn on top of each other so I’ll go from fighting a couple zombies to a group of 10.
Overall, this is really not a good game at all. It’s very clear that it was rushed out to cash in on the Dead Island hype with its majority of copy and pasted assets and mechanics, completely boring and forgettable story, sheer amount of bugs in the game and complete lack of anything new and exciting to make this game worth playing. If you really loved Dead Island then play the original, because honestly this feels like a half-finished, watered down version of the original.

Silly me, right? 
I wanted to take a break from Dead Island after the first game left me unsatisfied. But no, since I already installed Riptide alongside it, I decided to get it out of the way, so I'll have better horror games to play during October.

And little did I know: Dead Island Riptide manages to be better than the first game - not by a huge margin, but a noticeable one.

The world is more condensed than before and that actually works in its favour. Instead of several, mid-tier size maps, you instead get two large ones, each with a few subzones. That way the world itself feels more open for experimentation. Another huge draw for me was to play as the same character with the same level and abilities as in the first game. That way, I found my way around immediately and got to experiment with skills I hadn't chosen before. 

Gameplay this time involves a few missions where you defend your base from hordes of zombies. You also get new special infected, including mini bosses, who drop better loot on defeat. And in addition of a car, you can now also get around with a boat, at least in the first half. The obligatory city level is a lot more appealing this time, with parts being flooded and a mined out military base. 
Otherwise...it's just more Dead Island. You collect weapons, fight zombies, modify weapons and fight more zombies. And it relies heavily on fetch quests, so get ready to do lots of those.

Dead Island Riptide is a smaller game and I'm not complaing on that. It's brief, but far less annoying than the first game. Wait for a discount, though.

I'd place this game somewhere between Left4Dead and Dying light.

Pros vs left4dead:
- not so bad graphics and physics
- item creation, upgrade and trade system
- large and sophisticated inventory system
- more quests and story

Cons vs left4dead:
- character motor and animations could have been much better
- no AI to make your team play with you on single player (major bummer)
- some special effects can use a lot of improvment (particle systems etc)

pros vsdying light:
- being able to transport quest items in cars/boats
- story is a bit more consistent and interactive

cons vs dying light:
- no parkour and limited character abilities
- graphics much much outdated
- maps much smaller
- environment much less interactive

In the first half our i felt a bit of regret for buying it, but after that things got better and game is fun to play,
 but honestly they could have done much better in the area of inventory management and overall game physics.

Bottom line, despite some drawbacks, the game is worthy of playing and would probably appeal to anyone who's into survival games.

If you liked the first game then for sure I would buy the game, on sale of course. My main gripe was zombies throwing shit at me which 98% of the time insta kills you. Otherwise it was a fun game, haven't played dead island in years and this was a throw back with a good amount of new things added where it doesn't feel like a recycled game. Story on the other hand was just okay, it continues off the first game's story which is great but the ending just felt like it was lacking.

It's Dead Island's combat, but with only fetch quests and more backtracking. 5.7/10

The 'open world' of Riptide is horrible, frequently requiring vehicles or fully repaired weapons to traverse without being hampered by unlimited respawning zombies. If you didn't quit by the first area, the map opens up much more, and the fury boost does negate the endless hordes, by providing you an unlimited use ticket to murder for free. 

Quest design is laughable, with the game only consisting of fetch, escort and secure area objectives. Story is no better, and is not a good continuation of the original. Gun balance is out of the question, 1-4 shots on every enemy without durability, and free fountains of ammunition around the map. Exploration is confusing and poorly mapped, underground areas should be more clearly displayed as such. 

The only positives I found are, it's another Dead Island game and DI2 hasn't come out yet, I can turn my brain off and still finish it, and it didn't crash. 
Only play it if you get this with the Remastered DI, on a sale, and with at least one other person.

I thoroughly enjoyed the open world and the graphics that went along with it; even holds up to this day in my opinion. However, there were several things that disappointed me as a long time player of zombie games. 
The combat mechanics were not at all easy... this said after almost 60 hours of gameplay. I often found myself defenseless no matter how many points I put into my stamina and hand to hand combat. Keep in mind, this entire time, I was playing a character whose strength was firearms; I didn't find a single gun or blueprint for one (and I was looking for them too) until I was at least 80% through the game. Even after finding the blueprints and ultimately finishing the game, I was never able to craft ammo for myself.
The boss fights were a bit ridiculous considering that most of the creatures were not ones I'd come across before and therefore had no way to beat. I ended up looking up a lot of things on the internet before going into boss fights because my Casebook wasn't up to date with what I was about to face. 
Finally, no spoilers included; this was one of the most let down, disappointing, rage inducing ending I've ever experienced in a game. To me, it was an intense let down after everything I'd gone through.  
All in all, I think that the game had a lot of potential for what it COULD have been, but I certainly wouldn't recommend it or even play it again.

I played through the original and it was great.
The definitive edition truly didn't bring much.
It pretty much is just the exactly same game.
Sure, some visuals got an upgrade, but yeah.
This wasn't a free upgrade, It was expensive.
I bought the collection with riptide included.
The original owners had a discount for that.
It was around 9€ in total, I don't remember.
The level of improvement is very small, tho.
You could get mods for the original games.
Those mods also improved the visual style.
But unlike this, they were free to download.
Was this definitive upgrade worth it? Nope.
I just do not think it was a worthy upgrade.
It feels more like a cash-grab to be honest.
Nowadays you can't buy the originals, tho.
Therefore: It's great for all the new players.
Paying for the same games twice isn't fun.
Especially if there isn't anything truly new.
It is like paying for some cool visual mods.
But I really won't give it a negative review.
As I already said: It's nice for new players.
Only for that: I'm giving a positive review.

I know this comment will be helpful for the people who haven't bought it yet.
 There is a huge performance lag and stuttering even in high end computers for years and that is the main reason I haven’t been able to play this game more than quarter of its story since it has first came out. I also managed to fix the problem to some extend by starting the game with Nvidia graphics. However, there still seems to be a bit of visual performance problem because of the game itself.

 Other than that, If you played the first game and liked it, the only thing you may find here could be disappointment. Sure it can be a very nice game If you have friends to play. I can start the game play it 3 hours and get legendary weapons and unique thing, improve them to the max and stuff like that. Money is everywhere. The merchants are stacked. However, no matter how far I decrease the quality, performance still seems to have a problem. 

 The game is very short compared to the first one. The ambient is not as good because of being in a constant forest. Not like there are slums, hotel floors or anything concrete, just sand, water, plants, trees and even more plants.
There are a lot more firearm, a lot more bombs and a bit more melee weapons. Oh, and also there is a new character who is similar to Wolverine but with a staff. There are one or two extra skills added for the main character in the first game.
I was so hyped for this game when it first came out because like, I LOVED the first game. And I was very good in the first game. I would do an area attack even though I don’t have an area attack (in the first game). Maybe that was why I got so disappointed. This one was very much like a DLC of the first game. 

 All in all, I do not recommend riptide but I hella do recommend the first game.
Thank you for reading.

This game mainly feels like an expansion of the first Dead Island game
This one didn't age well.

===DISCLAIMER===
ENDING DISCUSSED. DO NOT READ IF YOU DON'T WANT TO BE SPOILED.

Rating at time of release = 8/10
Rating for current day = 5-6/10

I would've given this game a thumbs up back in the day of its original release, but time has not treated this title well. It was pretty good for its era, but time has done it no favors and other games (Dying Light is a prime example) show just how much of a difference a few years makes for this genre and how a more polished, finished-feeling game can hold up over time much better.

===REVIEW===
I really wanted to enjoy this game the way I did years ago when I played this game on my laptop, but I just couldn't. This game comes across as a rushed out sequel that has barely anything new to bring to the table, and the things it does bring to the table feel rushed and unpolished. Here is a list of the things (some in both titles, others only present in this title) that made this game about a 6/10 for me.

1. Movement system (Present in both games)
The movement system in this game makes it feel like the entire map is an ice rink. I understand the concept of momentum and what not, but the way it was incorporated just felt extremely awkward and uncomfortable. Having your character slide around like they're running on a soapy ice rink is extremely unfun, and it made fighting things like infected and butchers extremely unfun, since the act of them running into you alone is enough to make you want to pull your hair out.

2. AI Mechanics/Defend Location scenarios (Riptide Exclusive)
I don't remember it being this bad, but MAN do the "defend the location" parts suck so bad. Half the time your AI allies are bumping into you and causing you to go flying (goes hand in hand with issue 1), and they serve merely to be a distraction 90% of the time as opposed to actually being decent defense. These parts felt extremely unpolished, as it felt more of a "run around and finish off a cluster of zombies while your "allies" serve as punching bags for 10-15 minutes" instead of an actual, solid defense objective.

3. Game feels like it was designed around porting in old character/early game imbalance (Riptide Exclusive)
The original Dead Island felt a lot better in this regard, as leveling up actually took a bit of time and you couldn't get strong perks from the get go. In Riptide, the fact alone that you start at level 15 is more than enough to prove this point, but I'll take it one step further. Early game was significantly more difficult in the original, but Riptide early game is a joke. My most recent playthrough as John (just finished it earlier today) could not have been any easier than it was, and that is because you can get stupid strong perks right as you get off the ship. Critical hit perks in and of themselves are enough to make you a walking one man army (due to being able to kick a zombie down, punch each of their arms once, and instantly kill them), and the leveling pace is significantly faster. By the end of the original (did just about every side quest I came across in every region I came to), I believe I was in the mid 30s with a modest assortment of perks. By the end of Riptide (I rushed through the story and disregarded a lot of side quests), I was over level 50 with nearly maxed out combat skills and nearly maxed out survival (disregarded fury because it's easy as hell to get by without it). 

4. Combat was extremely annoying compared to the first (Riptide Exclusive)
This may have been a John exclusive issue, but it felt extremely annoying to fight anything. One punch sends them flying, and having to swing my mouse back and forth to keep up with how much knockback there was when fighting felt extremely tedious. It made me want to engage in LESS combat, since every fight just felt like punching them once, them falling down, and me beating them senseless all over the place until they died.

5. New enemy types are frustrating (Riptide Exclusive)
A lot of the new enemy types (excluding the grenadier, since it's a joke for the most part) are extremely annoying to deal with. The screamer is basically an infected with faster attack speed and the ability to stun you for 5 seconds, drowners were designed to make the boat sections annoying as hell (as if the boat sections weren't bad enough), and wrestlers are just more time-consuming thugs. The new enemy types just felt like a way to introduce more unpolished content, as the screamer's design doesn't even make any sense (why do they look like they belong in a Resident Evil game and not a quasi-apocalyptic zombie game?), the drowner is just a region-specific infected, and the wrestler is just a harder to kill thug.

6. Ending (specifically the boss fight) sucked
The story in and of itself had so many "out of left field" twists that had no build-up to them (Harlow was a good person, then a terrorist trying to steal the vaccine, then a good person trying to destroy anything related to the virus) (The virus was caused by the natives, then it was a bio-weapon, then it was basically a seasonal flu, then it was a bio-weapon again). On top of that, the final boss fight literally just felt like a way to f*** the heroes, as the fight was terrible and it was a cheap excuse to get the heroes to inject themselves with the mutagen and set up the "cliffhanger" at the end of the game. The only choice when fighting Harlow was to just spam M1 in her face (since you couldn't outrun her without jumping off of the upper catwalks) until the end phase where you get god mode and just spam M1 in her face (once again) until she dies. 

===SUMMARY===
I'm sure there's plenty of other things I forgot, but this was the majority of the problems I had with the game. Again, I understand that this is a game from 2013 and games have come a long way since then, but that still doesn't change the fact that the original holds up better over time (in my opinion) than Riptide and games like Dying Light hold up tremendously more than either of the two titles.

Where to even begin. 

I enjoyed the original Dead Island for what it was. A decently fun gore-fest RPG that had you mindlessly doing fetch quests and slaughtering zombies. I was excited to try Riptide because it appeared to be more of the same with the addition of more content.  

Much of the same problems I had with the original are still here. The game does not run all that well, the FOV is abysmal (CAMERA SHAKE) and the lack of basic information about weapon stats and upgrades is still here. Several times the audio would just bug out during fights and this happened A LOT. For some reason they included weapon proficiency...but I was never able to figure out what they did. I find this to be lazy of Tech Land as it was a frustrating aspect, they could have easily fixed. This game feels like an expansion more so than a standalone game. If you do not import a character, then you can start off with a level 15 character (for some reason) and they have included a 5th playable character. 

The game’s first act was enjoyable, you spend almost half the game on the mainland of the island. It’s a mix of jungle/bayou and introduces you to the personal quest system. It returned me to the fun parts of the original game where you can explore and drive all around the island. The island has been hit with a storm, so you must fight against the sluggish controls while slowly wading through water. The addition of a boat doesn’t really fix this as Tech Land made sure to introduce an annoying zombie type that quite literally spawns in midair and attempts to knock you off the boat (Get used to doing a quick time event 5-6 times in a row). The boat is buggy, and ramming does not work. The other new additions are some copy and pasted boss rooms, small horde battles during the quest (more on that later) and personal quests to upgrade your survivors. I had a lot of fun with upgrading the team and their ability to handle zombies does seem to increase the more you upgrade them. However, as you enter Henderson, the game just stops being fun. Henderson is a boring maze-like city only filled with repetitive side quests. You spend the latter half here and really everything you were doing in the first half sort of gives way to these repetitive tasks. Don’t even get me started on the ending. The final boss is hilariously bad. The story overall was bad. The Indigenous woman (Yoraba?) and your helicopter pilot from the original literally walk of camera and are never heard from again. 

I don’t really recommend it unless you really enjoyed the original and are willing to stick through a worse version of Dead Island.

A good zombie slayer title for anyone's collection. It isn't perfect, but it isn't horrible either. Try to catch it on sale.

 Two things I'd like to point out, though. There's a LOT of camera shaking, as well as head bobbing. Neither of which can be toggled on/off in the menus. Some say altering the Field of View in the DI files helps, and perhaps it does to some degree, but it definitely isn't a full "fix." So that said, keep it in mind when buying this. It doesn't make it completely unplayable, i just recommend taking a pause every so often and look away from the screen.

 The other thing can apply to all characters, as they all can throw weapons, but mainly focuses on our throwing expert, Logan. Fun character. Love the Boomerang proc chance for returnable throws. Here's where some things can be hanky, however. When Boomerang fails to proc, thrown weapons behave how.... well, how they normally would. Bladed weapons impale, making it for easy retrieval when you can't bank on Boomerang procs. Blunt weapons, however.... At times upon impacting an enemy, Blunt weapons can often take a REALLY odd trajectory and, more than you'd care for, can land in unreachable areas. I've lost some decent Unique Legendary quality weapons this way.

 In short, both DI and DI:Riptide are great zombie slayers, even more so if motion sickness isn't an issue for you. Throwing weapons is a great tactic, especially when a character's build revolves around it, just try to avoid throwing weapons like Hammers and Baseball Bats. They won't necessarily return to you like Mjolnir, and could be lost forever.
one of the best games ever

Such a bland game. Be it story, gameplay, progression, world traversal, everything!
Like it's truly a chore to play. I played the base game of Dead Island and it was also a tad boring in it's own right, but for some reason this game just went all the way in with the mediocrity, to such an extend that I felt the need to write a review to vent my frustrations.

The glaring flaw with this game is that the game's gameplay simply sucks. At a point it's just you hacking an ever increasing level of zombies and it never feels as if you're getting better gear or actually improving with the skill system in the game.

Another disappointing part of this game is that it's just unappealing to look at. Be it the eye straining motion blur and film grain (which can be disabled, but doesn't help) or the camera shake that just simply disorientates you every time you have to climb a ladder or when you're pushed down by a zombie.

Hopefully the story is good right? Wrong. Unfortunately the story is just a drag and never picks up steam, and the side characters makes it especially hard to not skip their conversations, close the game and play something else.

In the end I can not recommend this game, and would instead recommend you try Dying Light if you haven't already. That games does just about everything right that this game does wrong.

[b]What's it about?[/b]
Unlike Steam states, this is an up to 4 player co-op with 5 chars to choose from. It can also be played SP.
The mechanics and many other aspects are pretty similar to [i]Borderland 2[/i]. It is the sequel to [i]Dead Island.[/i]

[b] Compared to Dead Island:[/b]
[list]
[*]Thugs give you more of a fair chance melee-ing them.
[*]Rams are far less frequent.
[*]Cars still drive like tanks.
[*]I didn't like having to swap weapons non-stop in [i]Borderland 2[/i] while leveling up. The new weapon level system on its own would be a great idea. Sadly, it is just on top of the old weapon system from DI.
[/list]

[b]positive[/b]
[list]
[*]Ran apart from some audio glitches bug-free on Win10. Some weapons respawned multiple times in co-op.
[*]The island is beautiful and the level design is interesting.
[*]The zombie slashing is very satisfying.
[*]Huge plus: You have a choice whether to fight lieutenants in close combat or take them out from a safe distance.
[*]The voice actors do a decent job. They are a class above the rest of the game and make it enjoyable. Though their lines are still nothing special.
[*]Plays on Linux.
[/list]

[b]negative[/b]
It came out around the same time as [i]Borderland 2[/i] and has in my opinion nearly identical shortcomings, namely a forgettable story, lots of copy/paste and boring quests.
[list]
[*]Quests consist solely of fetch quests, area clearance and area defence, though you got a few co-op elements in it. The bodyguard quests from DI are gone.
[*]Z's respawn at the same rate and area on the spacious main island as on the far denser town, which is really tedious on the island.
[*]In many ways, you feel this could be a great game, if more time and money would have been invested. A good game to give to the fans really and let them fine-tune it. Fine-tuning is missing on skills and weapons.
[*]Durability on weapons adds to the tedious changing of weapons and has no benefit for the player IMHO.
[/list]

[b]Verdict[/b]
Has a bit of the island flair of [i]Far cry 3[/i] on a far smaller scale though combined with the [i]Borderland 2[/i] mechanic and makes for a solid fun game with friends, but is not interesting enough for SP explorers.

Honestly after playing the first one when I was a kid, I really thought the next one was gonna be really good. But after I came back to this game and revisited Riptide, I really found out how bad everything in this entire game is. There's zombies that can just insta kill you by throwing a knife at you, which is completely unavoidable, there's the fact that every zombie respawns when you leave the area, including any screamers or rams you previously killed, there's the fact that these characters can maybe swing there weapons 4 or 5 times before they're just standing there out of breath, and you get knocked to the floor, there's the durability on weapons, which after killing maybe 15 zombies, the weapon is no longer usable, you can get hit while going into cutscenes, get killed in cutscenes, or have zombies walking around in them. Also, most of the zombies they added into this game that weren't in the first one, is some of the worst content they could've possibly added. The screamer makes it to where your character just stands there for 5 seconds, letting all the zombies swarm around you and hit you while they're just holding their head, there's the dude with knives for arms, which looks cool, but is just some dude on crack who hits you enough times to use a medkit everytime you go to attack him, there's the horrible L4D boomer ripoff, which tanks hits, and throws up in a 360 degree radius, there's the wrestler, which is a horrible L4D2 charger ripoff, which is like the tank and the charger together, except completely useless, and there's also named zombies, which are purple skulls, which are usually several levels higher than you, and almost instantly killing you, (and NPC's). Also, there's almost nothing to spend your money on in this game, as none of the vendors sell anything useful. You find more useful gear on someone's lockbox in the middle of their bedroom. (Excluding the items given to you after a completed quest, those are usually good weapons.) Also, most of the story plots, could've been solved if anyone had some common sense in the entire game. We are out here trying to survive a zombie apocalypse, not make best pals and play patty cake in the California sun after it all blows over. The entire time I was just waiting for the game to end. I bought this game for me and a friend to play, but after about 20% in, he said the combat, story, and enemies were all so bad, he would never play it again. The achievement for beating this game is about 17%. and i'm not even surprised. Don't even get me started on the missions where you have to set up barricades, and defend against 4-5 waves of the zombie horde, and while you're doing all this, you need to defend the NPC's against zombies that have grabbed them, because they can't just push them off. If you're playing this game solo, every single NPC will have a zombie on them, that you have to get off, or you will fail the mission. Horrible story, horrible plot, horrible enemies, horrible game. I hate to say it since I enjoyed the first one a lot, but they really dropped the ball on this one, and judging by the 17% of people that have actually just finished the story, it looks like i'm not the only one who thinks like that.

I used to play this game a lot on my xbox 360. It is decent but is not at all better that the first game. The core mechanics of the game are great and satisfying, but you're better off just replaying the first game than playing this game. Much of the story is annoying and the "definitive edition" part is just a cash-grab. Actually, play dying light instead since it basically uses the same engine and all the same assets and animations but has slightly better story, great parkour, and plenty of other improvements

Although its story is pretty average, even though definetely better than the original, and the gameplay can be repetitive after a while, the game itself is not long enough to make you go bored. If you liked the first DI, you will like this one, if only to see the end of the story. The game works exactly the same as DI, so much so that it would be better of as an expansion or DLC for the first game. Grab this on a discount and it will be a nice 10 to 20 hours fun by killing zombies, just don't expect top-notch quality on it.

Dead Island Riptide provides in many ways more content than Dead Island does, it's in many ways superior. With a similar but in many ways different setting, new weapons, zombies, mods, and story; Riptide has a lot to offer. The experience let me see where the developers got their inspiration for Dying Light. Riptide allows you to run across rooftops, jump over obstacles and climb various things, plus a big part of Riptide takes place in the slums, similar to Dying Light. They even added a way to climb vines and rocks which I don't think was in Dead Island. It does a very amazing job of providing variety, switching the setting every few hours; one moment you're in the jungle, then you're in a sewer, on a rooftop, bungalow, theater, dock, laboratory... - this factor doesn't let the game get stale quick. This combined with constantly finding cool new weapons like snipers, revolvers, katanas, claws, swords, chainsaws, and a variety of mods really kept me going. The combat is the same as Dead Island, melee combat feels amazing while ranged combat is lacking in a lot of places; shooting with any type of gun doesn't feel rewarding and feels really heavy, but the melee combat is really, really well done. One of the main reasons I play a lot of zombie games is zombie variants, I love when there are a lot of interesting special infected to encouter and to beat the brains out of. Dead Island did zombie variants well, Riptide brings that to a whole other level adding more zombies like Drowners, Wrestlers, Grenadiers, Screamers, and other infected among the ones that were in Dead Island. That's a crazy ammount of variety. The cons of the game are sadly that it has a lot of bugs; sometimes a quest item you're looking for doesn't appear, items glitching through the map... The map itself and how it tracks quests is very annoying, I found myself getting lost more than I should. The story is also very bad, just like Dead Island, but it's not what you're playing the game for. The survivor AI is stupid af, if they bump into you during one of the parts where you have to hold your ground, you'll start bouncing around like a pin-ball. But, if you're willing to get past the bugs, you'll have a lot of fun in Riptide, I promise! :)

Do not waste even 5 dollars on this. Not worth any amount of money at all. It is literally Dead Island 1 just in a shorter worse story on an even worse map with half of it flooded. Flooded portions of the map make you run slow while zombies run full speed. The special enemies are not fun to fight against at all. The weapon drops are trash RNG and sometimes you can go through half the game without even getting a better upgrade. New character is a boring punch character that just heals off punches and crits with punches. So original. All the special moves take too long or feel off to use. Better off just spamming left click. For some weird reason you still play it through it all, you will notice the game has a terrible ending that just puts a middle finger to you for making it that far. The boss fight is just some traitor character that is pretty obvious but you can literally beat it by spamming left click the entire time stunlocking it. Can hardly call this a game with how barebones it is. You will feel how lacking it is with the broken sidequests, awful weapon variety, enemy spam as they respawn all the time, and terrible animations/voice work. Go buy anything else on sale, this is only fun with friends so you can make fun of how awful it is.

Dead Island: Riptide Definitive Edition is a zombie open world survival sequal to Dead Island. It feels worse than the first game , and the first game was the very definition of a meh game. It added very little, only a new charcter, some weapons, and maybe an ability. So the game starts where the first left off, the survivors being rescued by the military, but "surprisingly" they wanted to experiment on them. The ship gets shipwrecked on another different island with a "surprisingly" zombie problem. You start in the jungle this time, which was a low point in the first game, I kept getting lost and the boat is a BAD vehicle. I will never urderstand the reasons why zombies can run through high water and you can't. The story is bad and not as "good" as the first game's. Just boring overall gameplay. One cool thing was that you could import your character from the first game into this one.  And I give this a 2/10.

A horrific zombie game, and not in a good way. I'll start with the sort of good points, the visuals are actually pretty decent, considering age, and the combat can be fun depending on your character type, but now it all goes downhill from here. The plot is atrocious, being a direct sequel to the first game which already had a pretty poor story, comprised of typical government conspiracy and bio-weapon testing, and some sort of tribal voodoo creating the virus that takes itself way too seriously. Horrible voice acting 'compliments' the disgusting quest design, which are all fetch quests that have you running to the other side of the map then back again to make some seriously tedious gameplay. The actual combat is lacklustre, having a few 'special zombies' thrown into the hordes of flesh eaters, some of which only appear for a mere 2 minutes total which is disappointing. Combat is easily this games best feature, but it isn't saying much considering the whole thing, satisfying killing and creative weapons are usable by a few different classes/characters with different strong suits and abilities, which adds some replayability if you *really* want to play this thing again. 4/10, possibly fun and visually appealing combat hindered by horrible everything else.

[h1] [i] The best way to play original Dead Island [/i] [/h1]Dead Island Riptide is basically Dead Island 1.5. Although it is a sequel in terms of story, gameplay and graphics stay the same with a few additions. No much explaining needed - if you liked original Dead Island, Riptide won't disappoint you - it has everything the original had and few extras such as new weapons, useful skills, upgrades and map. The only thing that was done worse is arguably story. Still - it is worth to pick up, especially coated in Definitive Edition graphics.Pros:+ Definitive edition remastered graphics+ New map looks sweet and offers more variety than the first game+ New skills, upgrades and weapons+ New character+ LenghtCons:- Main story is a bit worse than the OG- Bugs and glitches

Very much like its predecessor Dead Island Riptide is a good game if you want to do some zombie slaying either alone or in co-op. The locations are fewer but of about the same quality, the ambience is well done and maybe even a little creepier at times than Dead Island. It remains quite a bit buggy in its gameplay, the graphics are increased in the definitive edition nothing incredible but it's still nice to see. I enjoyed the story a bit more as it felt more serious but not that much better than I would call it gripping either. You can import your character and the skill trees are expanded so you can level past 50, there is also weapon levels (blunt, sharp, hand-to-hand, firearms) that you get xp by simply using them giving a perk every level up to 10 so you don't feel like using a wet noodle when trying something your character isn't specialised in. It's a bit shorter but it remains good if you enjoyed the first game you will most likely enjoy this one as it's mostly a slightly improved version of it. It's still nothing incredible but if you want more zombie slaying action and have free time available try it.

I originally bought the first game when it was released to sate my appetite for fun cooperative zombie games' at the time  we were  ''played out'' on Left 4 Dead 1 & 2.  So we had turned to another zombie franchise Dead Rising, but I'd found it a little tedious for reasons I can no longer remember exactly.  Anyway, playing with good online friends is a blast and we were part way through playing Dead Island when Riptide was released, so I bought it immediately, and started the single player campaign in between playing the 1st game with friends, but TBH, I found Riptide just didn't feel as good; so it was put aside for almost 7 years until this April,  when I'd first returned to Dead Island to play with three other online friends (I'd abandoned both games because of losing my best friend with whom I was playing the first game cooperatively eight years ago.

[b]Fast forward 7 years.[/b]

We'd thoroughly enjoyed the recent foray into Banai (playing it weekly for a few hours from last Nov 19 to April 20) & after completing all chapters decided to jump into Palanai together.  By this time Riptide had been re-released as the definitive edition, which I presume meant all the DLC from the original release had been incorporated, plus the  graphics had been overhauled. 

Although I loved the 1st game, my opinion of Riptide  has been totally reversed from my original thoughts.  Not only is it just as good as the original; Riptide has been upgraded to include some excellent changes such as item pick up's which in the first game were only available to the first player accessing the pick up or weapon locker; whereas in Riptide everyone gets to pick the item or weapon up; which in my opinion is much  fairer and leads to less rushing to get the decent weapons etc.  Also, when you first start, you already have some of the perks selected depending on which character you choose to play; e.g. the gun specialist Purna already has some Rage perks added, which give her extra shots when in rage mode. On top of this other challenges have been added that are completed in stages. As you progress, you are notified by messages on screen that you have attained a specific level in that particular challenge, for example cutting of a certain number of heads. When you complete aany challenge you are awarded XP towards your next level. 

We as a group are still only on chapter three of Riptide, and about to enter Henderson town once we've finished the last of the side quests in the first area, so I'll edit this short review at some point, once we've completed the game.  We found that if we played without one of the group the quests would become a little confusing because  whoever had missed the previous game would not have various  quests completed or have missed picking up a decent modification or other important item, and it often led to us having to repeat quests just so they could catch up. Sometimes it was also necessary to have completed a particular quest before you could  accept others.  So when we started Riptide we decided that if one of the group couldn't play, the remainder of the group would jump into one of the many other zombie games or other co-op games available.

The  original graphics were much the same as the first game, but the definitive edition  that included all the old DLC plus a graphics overhaul doesn't seem that different from the original Riptide.   Despite the games age it still looks great (IMO) despite many official reviews lambasting it for lacklustre graphics.  I've also noticed that when joining the shared game there isn't the same issues as with the 1st one, where if you didn't click on the space bar when the cut scene started, you'd have to sit through the whole scene, and often have to reboot the game before being able to join. 

The game play is similar to the original, apart from the pick up changes mentioned above,  there are new infected with different ways of attacking and although the maps are set in similar environments, the first three chapters based in Palanai & the flooded swamp land look a lot different than the  jungle map in the first game.  I can't comment on Henderson yet. It looks set out differently looking at it's [url=https://www.ign.com/maps/dead-island-riptide/henderson][b]interactive map[/b][/url], and from the images I see it looks more Spanish colonial and definitely different to Banoi town. There's a nice selection of side & repeatable quests that see's your group traversing the area in search of various quest items.  There's no through route for vehicles, so travelling in vehicles is not as enjoyable as the original game.  Overall my group are thoroughly enjoying the co-op experience  and  highly recommend the game to anyone who enjoys playing with friends, especially if you are connected via Discord as well.  As for the SP campaign,  I've only played the beginning & that was in the original version just after it had been released and before it was updated and given an HD overall.  At the time, as already mentioned, I wasn't impressed; but, losing one of the  friends I played with  to cancer and other  games I'd purchase back then  stopped me continuing until now.

[b]Some useful  advice:[/b]

Before you start the game, or at least once you've  met  each of the different types of infected of which there are 13 types you should check out Dr Kessler's Casebook that's available via the Extra's  button,  which details all of the different infected types as well as their strengths and weaknesses.  You can also change the overall game play via the options to make it slighter harder or easier by  adjusting specific attributes such as  removing or adding hints, removing or adding  navigation on the mini map or removing  place markers on the main map and even the infected's health  bars.For those into collecting achievements, there's at least 35 to collect.

The continuation of Dead Island has struck me even more. Although it's not a formerly sought-after resort, the locations impress with their gorgeousness bordering on hopelessness. Picturesque jungle of Palanai and a welcoming town Henderson are also full of walkers. New mutants Grenadier, Wrestler, and Screamer appear in these locations, adding more trouble to the main characters. Moreover, it's possible to integrate the progress from the original game or choose a brand-new guy John with his skills. Perks such as new weapons, collectibles, getting around by boat, and base defense operations garnish this series. Lastly, the music there is just splendid and often heartbreaking. It helps to feel the game and forget about the mundane reality.
The only thing that I dislike is that the developers have removed weather changes, which is so discouraging. I like this effect a lot in the original version.

Even in 2020 this is still a fun game and good graphics, plus you don't need a top of the line GPU to play this smoothly.  After more than 200hrs on Dead Island and 88hrs on Riptide I always come back to this game when I want to have fun playing an open world shooter game. I also have Dying Light but Dead Island has better combat dynamics and specially more freedom to explore missions whenever you desire.  I've got tired of the dark atmosphere and the rigid play of many games in this class.  Resident Evil for example, is always dark places, kind of depressing and feels like a guided tour.  Dead Island is total exploratory freedom, mostly open field, sunny days, great landscapes, also buildings, cars, ships, rocks, sand, water, you have it all here.  There are some program errors but nothing to bad.  Many different options for weapons and grenades, it has it all.  Can't wait until they release Dead Island 2.

Far better than the original, you can use a boat to grind zombies to spray, kill some named horrors, and have some great town challenges.  I miss the sewers of the last game, but the hordes swarming your defenses made up for it.   I recommend this as fine pandemic fare.  Just running around killing zombies is relaxing.

I used to play this on the xbox 360 when I had no standards, but playing this again on PC is a different experience. My life is too short to play this mediocre game, there are some cool moments and characters but it's hard to stand this overwhelming boredom.

In comparison to the original dead island this game is worse, but it has some aspects that I feel are better. 

The gun play is much better, a huge aspect to that, ammo is more available though out the map, more selection of guns, and a better feeling with them. As well, Hand to hand weapons feel the same with more additions to them.

Yes, I'd recommend this, but I'd rather give it a 'meh' rather than yes or no for a review. What do I mean by that? Well, I'll break it down. This is basically more of the same as the original DI. The combat, shooting and everything is generally the same. Same weapons, mod types and vehicles. I am a huge fan of both DI and DI:R, but out of the two, I've played this game less than the original, having completed the campaign twice, once on the original and once on the Definitive Edition.

Starting with the good, this game has a far more creepier and unsettling atmosphere than the original. The original has got some jumpscare moments born from sudden attacks by hidden zombies and the infected, but this is far scarier to traverse than the original. There are also some great new mods and weapons, such as the sniper rifles, which are a GODSEND for dealing with the special infected. There's also a new character, John Morgan, a primarily hand-to-hand character and the story picks up right after the ending cutscene of the original game. The old cast is still here in all their glory, as well as new locations and infected to spice it up. There's also a new mode of transport, the boat, which is faster to travel around the jungle but has the added risk of waking all the sleeping drowners in the waterways. Dotted around Henderson and the jungle are various dead zones which act as dungeons filled with walkers and several special infected which makes a nice risk/reward dynamic.

What do I think of the new roster of enemies? Well, they're a mixed bag. We've got all the fan favourites from the previous game, being the walker, infected, thug, butcher, ram, suicider and floater, but we've got some new ones. The least dangerous is the drowner, basically an infected which hides in the water until you come near, when it will suddenly wake up and behave like a normal infected. The next is the grenadier, which is sort of like a reskinned floater. It's a large, slow to turn zombie which hits you from range and is mostly immune to fire damage. Sound familiar? Yep, it's the floater all over again but this time he's got a gas tank on his back which will explode when punctured for an easy kill! We've then got the wrestler, a grotesque monster which a large, swelled up and meaty arm which it will swing and slam into the ground like a club. No real vulnerability other than some slow movement and it's the second most scary and dangerous of the new additions. The final, scariest and downright annoying one is the screamer. Oh my god, the screamer! This thing is like an infected, but when it sees you, it will run up to you at PACE, the same as an infected, before screaming in your face! This will stun you and cause your character to cover their ears, blurring your screen and making you vulnerable, where the screamer will rapidly attack you. Guaranteed dead if this happens to you. This is why snipers are a must when you find these, as a few shots from far away will deal with them but they're TERRIFYING to deal with!

What's bad then, since I'm already being rather negative. Well, for a start, they ramped up the difficulty, which would not be so bad if they didn't chuck EVERYTHING at you in the first area of the game. Remember how it was laid out in Dead Island? You first met walkers and infected when you are very weak and don't have good weapons or stats. Then you meet thugs and suiciders to slowly raise the stakes. You build up and get some skills before meeting rams in Morseby and later on floaters in the sewers. You finally meet the dangerous butchers in the jungle but you've got better weapons and have a chance to deal with them. The first area you're in is the flooded jungle, but instead of just have walkers, infected, drowners and maybe floaters because of all the water, you get everyone! All of the old zombies are right there from the get-go and when you don'y have any mod blueprints, good weapons or perks, this makes the whole thing a drag as you grind up XP for perks and to buy weapons so you actually a chance.

What else? Well, there's the nightmare which is Halai village which has infected spawners. Yes, that's right, infected SPAWNERS. What do I mean by that? Well, normally zombies will respawn after the player has left the area or has been away for a certain amount of time. Here, the infected will constantly spawn on the rooves of certain houses for as long as the player stays in the area. It's not like they're well hidden either, the houses they spawn in are obvious as there's a square hole cut in them where you can literally see the infected climb out of. This makes the whole thing tedious as going anywhere in Halai means you'll constantly be chased by infected and after a point they just become annoying rather than scary.

Overall, do I recommend DI:R? At a push, yes. For a fan of the series like I am, it's a fun time with all the same physics and crazy weapon mods as before and once you're past the flooded jungle portion of the game, it starts being fun as Henderson is beautiful to traverse with no annoying infected spawners and it's more pleasant to look at compared to Moresby. The new weapons and mods are fun and a good addition to the already rather large stockpile from the original DI and the new infected add in a new dynamic of where's safe and where's not. They add a challenge but none of them are too OP or break the experience (although the screamer can go suck on my sniper rifle). It's not as fun as the original and you can probably give it a miss if you weren't drawn in by the original.

Some people complain that Dead Island Riptide is essentially just an expansion pack of the original Dead Island. I disagree. The combat has been reworked so that it flows better and you're less likely to run out of stamina in the middle of a fight, plenty of fun new weapons have been added (the flare gun, the harpoon gun and mines to name just a few), new enemies (like the grenadier), and it fully embraces the deadzones/dungeons. 

If you liked the original Dead Island, but wished it was less glitchy and had more variety of weapons and enemies, then this is the game for you. It's fun on your own, but hilarious with a friend.

I will list the few annoyances I have come up with:  Takes a long time to level up, multiplayer voice chat is broke, The Map is really not the biggest and they make a point to force you to take incredibly round about ways to get anywhere, and Legendary items don't seem to drop very often.

If you have any questions about the game go ahead and comment and I will try to get to it.

Отличное высококачественное издание, той самой багованной игры на новом движке от Dying Light

Ощущение что игру делали 2-3 человека по быстрому, без тестирования и полировки.

А теперь по порядку:

* Мыло продолжает лидировать среди лучших эффектов во всех играх Techland
* Странная производительность с просадками до 40 fps
* Странные булькающие звуки
* FOV уменьшили
* Сломанная механика зомбо-обнимашки
* Перепутанные звуки у зомби
* Зомби могут замахиваться на тебя не нанося урона
* Очень заметная подгрузка текстур, местами они даже не прогружаются, оставаясь мыльными
* Сломанная механика ЕЖ персонажа
* Местами зомби сами испускают дух, даже если их не трогать
* Перебор с освещение
* Сломанная механика инвентаря (пропадают аптечки)
* Странное поведение игры, с пропаданием транспорта если отойти по делам
* Большая вероятность что персонажа придавит дверью машины
* Не всегда получится сбить зараженных (бегающие зомби), ведь при попытке сбить, они забегают на крышу

[bugfix] Зомби кидающий в персонажа нож не убивает его
[bugfix] Нельзя телепортироваться на место водителя стоя у другой двери

Я думаю Techland отлично постаралась в этой игре, чтобы игроки не скучали а были в постоянном напряжении и в постоянном поиске очередных неизведанных глюков и багов.


Excellent high-quality edition of the very buggy game on the new engine from Dying Light

The feeling that the game was made by 2-3 people quickly, without testing and polishing.

And now, in order:

* Soap effects continues to lead among the best effects in all Techland games
* Strange performance with drawdowns up to 40 fps
* Strange gurgling sounds
* FOV reduced
* Broken zombie attack and hug mechanics
* Wrong zombie sounds
* Zombies can swipe at you without causing damage
* Very noticeable texture loading, sometimes they do not even load, remaining soapy
* Broken mechanics with HP character
* Zombies themselves dying without no reason, even if you do not touch them
* Overloaded lighting
* Broken inventory mechanics (first aid kits disappear)
* Strange behavior of the game, with the loss of transport if you go away on business
* It is very likely that the character will hurt by the car door
* It’s not always possible to bring down infected by car (running zombies), because when you try to squash them, they run onto the roof

[bugfix] Zombies throwing a knife at a character does not kill him
[bugfix] You cannot teleport to the driver’s seat while standing at another door

I think Techland did a great job in this game so that the players do not get bored but are in constant tension and in constant search for new unknown glitches and bugs.

Despite the mixed negative reviews, this is quite a good game. I can understand why some people have the gripes that they do, but nothing in this game detracts from an over all, positive experience. You will encounter an occasional glitch here and there, where a zombie might clip through a wall or part of the landscape, but these are few and far between, and when it does happen, it isn't so dramatic or awful that it takes you out of the experience. Obviously, this game has a huge Dying Light vibe and it's almost what I would refer to as a beta Dying Light, although, it's polished enough that I wouldn't consider it a beta game. Several years ago, when this released, it was more than polished to be a retail release. Now days, I can see why people are a little more critical. Still, this is a fun game and if you like zombie games like Dying Light, this is a no-brainer!

I played the original back in 2013 and I just don't remember it being this hard. For starters, if you import your character from Dead Island you will lose all of your weapons. I remeber keeping my weapons on the original. Zombies respawn way, way too quickly, so you're constantly being harassed. There are far fewer energy drinks and snack bars, at least on act 1, and that makes the beginning really hard, because you're low on cash and can't really afford to buy medkits and new weapons. By the way, the weapons the game provides you at the start are really weak. I was lvl 39 when I started this game and all the zombies were 41 or higher. So you have less damage, less money, awful damage and far more dangerous zombies. The mini map is always bugged, meaning the path to objectives rarely ever show up, and since the map is confusing, it makes it really hard to move around. Also, when on the boat your friend cannot defend it against those annoying water zombies. If you are driving, your friend is always being attacked and you have to drop from the boat to defend him, since those water zombies pull him off the boat. It's just insane. Having a friend in this game actually makes it harder. I finished the first one in 27 hours, all by myself and by completing all missions. This is worst than the original. Don't buy it if you have the original, unless you want to play with some one, since the original is off the market and you couldn't play multiplayer on it even if your friend also owned the original.
