Holy Shit, this game is a shit show. I usually do very non-serious reviews as a joke but i feel like i have to say something about this game.

I bought this while it was on sale, i was feeling nostalgic from when i first played the game on console and used the discount coupon you get from the winter sale. Now i would say that i am grateful that i got it for free, but now i really just wish i didn't get this game at all and saved my coupon for something else. It was so much worse from what i had remembered
 
The game is a buggy mess, undead will clip through the wall and floors, sometimes you'll die instantly to doors, cars are extremely hard to drive, and some undead just won't take any damage but instead stay there with all your swings with your weapon going through it. The game's bugs remind me of the initial launch of games such as warframe or more recently borderlands 3 but instead the bugs stayed for the whole life span of the game and so on.

The models in the game were mediocre at best but gave them the benefit of the doubt that it couldn't get any worse and just a side affect from the limited technology we had in 2013 (the same year this game came out). To nobody's surprise it did get worse, models would noclip into buildings, animation when they talked was extremely choppy, and sometimes npcs wouldn't move from a spot no matter what the situation was to the point undead phased through them.

There are so many bugs, problems, and gameplay issues that saying it's mediocre is perfect for the game, it's the definition of borderline mediocre. If you see this game on sale, please don't take the 5$ deal, it's not worth it.

Expansion packs are a pretty hit and miss experience. Change a game too much and it loses it’s magic. Change it too little and it is a rehash and not worth the money. It is a balancing act and one that Dead Island Riptide does a good job at. I had played the original Riptide back on Windows but not much since it would crash often in the first ten minutes. I didn’t have any of those issues with the Linux version of the Definitive Edition thankfully. 

	Once again you can pick from the 4 different characters to play as. You can import your save file from the original dead Island Definitive Edition if you kept it. The story continues from the first as your group is still trying to escape the zombie outbreak. Without going into too much of a spoiler you get stuck on a different island. This allows the developers to reuse a lot of assets and can be seen as a tad lazy but overall the story was decently executed. It adds several new secondary characters for you to interact with. They all are very similar as the original as they just serve as basic quest givers and don’t go into a deep backstory. The game adds a new mode of travel in the form of a boat. It is fun to use since you can use the engine blade to hack up zombies. It is also optional so if you prefer to walk or drive to places you still can.  The weapons and skills are very much the same as the original which is familiar if not a bit too much so. You can also traverse the landscape by climbing rocks and vines which while is a nice addition, it also is usually required to get to certain places instead of being an optional way to get to a location in multiple ways. Combat is still very satisfying as before and playing solo was still very doable.

	There were still some issues that never got fixed from the original such as enemies being able to one hit kill me by throwing knives at me even though they are very low end weapons and I was at full health. I also encountered a glitch where I had to click on a boat to install the motor but the boat wasn’t clickable. I had to reload the game and it was then clickable and I could progress. In another part of the game I crouched to enter a hallway that had rubble so I could search a container for loot but I was then unable to get out as I was too tall to do so even when crouched. Once again I had to reload to before I entered the hallway. Sometimes bodies would flicker for a second or two but never for longer and only a handful of times in my playthrough. One other isuse was there was no option to remap the key you use to throw a flare and that happens to be the button I use to kick. While I could choose another button to kick let’s just say I wasted a great many flares as old habits die hard. A few times a sound effect was missing. Such as when I hit or shoot a zombie no sound would play. Once again this only happened a couple times through my playthrough.

	I played Dead Island Definitive Edition on Linux. Like the original Definitive Edition it suffered from an issue where the game would crash before loading the main menu. Like the original this was caused by a file called “LibGL.so”. The game was made to only work with a specific version of that file. As you can imagine over the years updated versions of have been made. The game will crash with anything newer than that version and no distro I tried uses one that old. The file is also not included with the game, it uses whichever version your OS has installed. I had to download a copy of the correct version file and drop it into the game folder. Once I did this the game launched just fine. The performance was great as well. I ran the game maxed out at 1080P and my FPS was usually 80-100 or higher. It supported framerates above 60 which was fantastic. There was no manual saving but the game auto saves after every completed task so it isn’t terrible although I would prefer manual save. There was support for Vsync, one AA setting, one ambient occlusion setting, as well as 7 other settings to tweak.  Alt-Tab worked just fine. The game did not crash at all during play. My CPU usage during gameplay was usually around 39%, my system RAM usage was usually around 5.3GB. The game took up 9.45 GB of storage and uses Techland’s own engine called Chrome Engine 5. I played version 1.1.2 of the game.

	I paid $3.30 CAD for Dead Island Definitive Edition. I can say that for how much fun it was it is easily worth $50 CAD. If you enjoy action games, co-op games, zombie games, give it a try if you haven’t already.  It adds to the Dead Island story well and while not innovating a ton it is still a great game at it’s core. It has some bugs and issues but none overshadow the fun I had. I finished a solo playthrough in just under 19 hours.

If you love zombie shooter games then Dead Island can't be missed. Sure, it has weird ass bugs, unintuitive gameplay, bad cutscene character movements, etc, etc. But you can easily play this for 40 hrs of pretty much pure action play. It's not an easy game per se, you will die in the most BS ways. Sometimes due to overpowered specials, sometimes by buggy interactions. The zombies scale with you so you're pretty much leveling for the points. The weapons eventually make it easier to deal with crowds of zombos. Overall, I must say, you don't play Dead Island for the story, but more for the actual world itself and being able to kill zombies . That ending was just horrible in my opinion. Didn't leave me with anything to feel good about after I finished it. Just left a bad taste in my mouth. But it's interesting, mostly has its fun moments (along with dragging moments of back and forth travel) and it is entertaining. Oh and btw, this game also extremely favors throwing sharp weapons at enemies. It's kind of lame that way. Cheers!
Excellent game that runs very smoothly on modern systems and provides plenty of gameplay.

Writing this review after putting 23 hours into the first game and just finishing this game with 11 hours. These hours reflect two things: I did all available side quests, and I loot pretty much everything I come across. I reviewed the first game, so now I come to review the second. In regards to the new story, it's okay. The game being half as short as the previous would have been excusable if it was not so repetitive in its design. While that is a negative of the game, I still pushed through and enjoyed it. The game is much more punishing with its combat and new enemy types than its predecessor, and I suggest importing your previous Dead Island character since it is easier that way. One huge complaint that I have is navigating the map for quests is awful. The first game did this right, but even with a new vehicle(it was a good idea, but executed poorly), I had to constantly open my map to consider possible routes for the quests. Overall, it's a decent game, and but do not pay full price. I got both games on sale, and they are worth it at a good discounted price The series as a whole is fun, and I look forward to playing Dying Light again at some point. Cheers.

Dead Island Riptide is a complete game in itself, rather than being an expansion or dlc of the first game. The story is pretty good, the graphics are excellent, sound and voice-acting all great, lots of collectibles to find, lots of quests. There are a few new additions to the game, like different zombie enemies and attack moves but everything is pretty much exactly the same as the first game. A playthrough took me about 30 hours.

A few negatives - like the first game there are lots of bugs and glitches in the sound, graphics, enemy AI etc. Nothing that ruins the game but its something that should have been fixed. It also has a really bad ending, just a total mess of an end mission that feels thrown together at the last minute.

But overall, great zombie-killing fun, a gorgeous looking open-world to explore and a worthy sequel to Dead Island. If you liked the first game, you'll like this.

Originally bought the game when it released on the PlayStation 3 and loved it quite a bit. 
Years later finally purchasing and playing through Steam, and remembering how sluggish the combat and movement were.

The various bugs that plague the game from weapons that are dropped and vanish, zombies spawning out of nowhere, and targeting AI right through walls and floors to perform the dive execution, zombies walking right over placed mines, etc.

Freshly starting the game, melee weapons are very lack-luster and feel almost useless, up until you get your first gun and then the game becomes very trivial.. especially to the point where you find the sniper rifle. But the sniper rifle is one of the reasons I fell in love with this game in the first place.. ironic isn't it?

With that all being said, I really do love the game, I just wish it were longer.. and now I patiently wait for the release of Dead Island 2.

Essentially a 20-40 hour long zombie-smashing simulator, the combat is fun and engaging, requiring you to watch and learn the different attacks that distinct zombie types can throw, and react accordingly by either dodging, kicking, running, swinging, shooting, or using character-specific special moves. Specific body parts can be targeted to cripple, topple or execute zombies strategically, and different weapon classes are designed to excell at either action, to swing wider for crowd control, to have longer reach, etc. Running blindly into zombies swinging a weapon will get you killed very fast.

The story is cheesy and quests all involve combat in one way or another, and fetching, lots and lots of fetching, so if the combat doesn't sound appealing to you this game will bore you to death, since it's it´s only redeeming quality and 90% of the gameplay.

You may also run into a bug or two and random stutters, if you don't tolerate stuff like this don't get this game.

Just as I loved Dead Island, I love Dead Island Riptide as well. Dead Island Riptide Definitive Edition is a remaster of the old version of Dead Island Riptide. This time the game is using the same engine of Dying Light which explains how it looks pretty.

The game carries progress from your past game but if it fails to detect your old saves (which happened to me since I played the original Dead Island game instead of the DE version), they would just give you X amounts of points and you assign however you want.

The game's mechanics and system is pretty much the same as the first Dead Island and they just added a new character to play as. If you enjoyed the first game's systems, then you should be fine but if you expected more, then you will probably be disappointed.

The story is kind of okay since it isn't as lengthy as the first game. The goal in this game is pretty much the same as the first game, "GET OFF THE F***IN ISLAND!!!!!" Additionally most characters return in this game but sadly, they never got to push the plot further with some of the other old characters [spoiler] but instead waste a bit of time making us learn new characters that either dies or just not heard from again later.[/spoiler] The only good story parts are when you find the audio logs since the voice acting is very convincing and it can make you feel for those guys.

The world/levels of the game is alright. There are like 2 large portions of the map in the game unlike the first one being like 3 or 4. There are some bugs like colliding with plant life and some of the levels don't explain why you have only 1 way to access a location. The game also acts like a MMO where players can go raid a small area (Dead Zones) to gain some good loot and the Dead Zone levels are mostly repetitive though.

Lastly, the multiplayer. I didn't play with friends at all and I only played it once with a random stranger which ended up making the experience bitter since the player didn't help me in the defending the fort section. I would recommend multiplayer though since you can create crazy and funny experiences in this game with friends and some zombies are tough to fight alone.

If you want to just watch me play the game, check out my videos of it here: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLX761ogOIyK2aRVhBliXOa4GwUsT7lYKh

Definitely not as good as the first game, now I guess I played the first game on console, but the second game takes away a few of the primary things that made one fun for me.

1. An actual start over instead of starting at level 15 with be nice.

I know you can just do custom instead, so as far as presets go it doesn't really matter, but immediately having 14 points is ridiculous, instead, you could have 14 more levels to gain to get the fun out of getting more points to spend ! 

It's almost like when you use something like cheat engine (Basically just cheating/hacking) for other games, it eventually takes all the the fun out of it, as does starting at level 15 for me, this may not be a huge issue but like it does for me, and possibly other people, it takes a big part of the fun out of it, and frankly, starting any level higher than 1 seems kind of pointless to have unless it's paid for or some other logical reason. (Not an extremely needed change to the game but it's just my suggestion anyway)

2. Aiming was actually a lot different that I expected, now this could just be a major problem from going console to pc, or maybe the devs just have to work on their aiming system for pc players, just doesn't feel as smooth and doesn't seem like they put a lot of effort into making it user-friendly as it should be.

Let's think about this, you could have an entirely PERFECT game on everything besides aiming, and for fps type of games that can ruin the ENTIRE game and makes the rest of the effort put into it seem pointless, now unless you only play games for the story, not really the gameplay, this will affect just like any other game with this sort of issue in a hugely negative way. Whether taking some of the fun out of it or a consistent annoyance, I think it's something to be improved upon. (Should probably be fixed/change or whatever you devs can do to help fix it would be nice !)

Reposting this from my refund reason to Steam Support:

This game did not age well. I remember having fond memories of playing it; which is why I bought it. But after the first thirty minutes, it felt like a deadbeat and dull experience. The story line is D-tier at best, and I'm being generous. It's such a painstakingly vague yet simple backstory, it's like it's trying to reel in it's viewer with it's "mysterious" plot line and reveals. The story is filled with so much cliche's, it's not even ironically endearing. It's just boring. 

What I think really takes the cake, is the fact that the game play mechanics don't even make up for the story. When you kill a Walker or finish off a Thug, it doesn't give you any satisfaction or sense of accomplishment. The event that ends up being the most enjoyable is the Prologue, which temporarily allows you to mow down a horde of walkers with a rifle; and even that only felt.. approximately okay. 

The leveling and upgrade system works very simply, and the upgrades don't get any more interesting than *maybe* a new ability, or just a slight damage/handling upgrade to something that already coexisted in your inventory. 

The walkers/thugs' attack patterns are extremely easy to follow, but they take such a long time to kill. It's not hard to lose your patience after taking five minutes to kill three zombies. The A.I also act like idiots and deal no damage, so you have to be the piggy-back hero for all of them; which is meticulous and boring. 

Replaying Dead Island: Riptide on PC has affirmed my decision about this game. It's an extremely underwhelming experience, and I'm ashamed that I blew twenty-bucks to experience nothing but immense disappointment. I didn't even get a good sense of nostalgia from playing it. 

If this game was free, it wouldn't have been worth the money.

Dead Island Riptide Definitive Edition is the HD remaster of the original sequel to Dead Island. 

Story:

Taking place immediately after the events of the first game, as the survivors are trying to get away from the zombie infested island of Banoi. After the helicopter they used to escape with is put down on a military ship they soon find the ship overrun with zombies and get shipwrecked on a new island of Palanai which is as well infested with Zombies. So you have to find a way of this island before the military will nuke it.

The story in Dead Island Riptide is terrible. Which is no surprise considering how bad the story was in the first Dead Island game was. Many characters do things that endanger other peoples lives and a lot of the plot feels very samey as you get stuck on an island and have to escape. It honestly feels like the script just swapped certain characters with new ones.

Graphics:

The graphics like Dead Island Definitive Edition are good, but only for environments as the NPC character models are absolutely awful looking like they are already dead and got up from their graves. The environments however are great and looks rather impressive. A lot of the island is absolutely beautiful and it's fun to explore the island and see the sights 

Audio:

The voice acting is absolutely horrendous, pretty much everyone does a terrible job. A lot of the characters put on these really fake accents and they are really off putting. The funniest one is the new character named Logan who has one of the worst Australian accents I've ever heard.  The audio also has the same glitches featured in the first definitive edition so when you get a critical strike it echoes so loudly it will make you go deaf.

Gameplay:

The gameplay in Dead Island games is both fun and frustrating. The game like the previous one is focused mainly on melee combat, with some firepower sprinkled throughout, but just like the first game the guns are absolutely worthless and not even worth bothering with unless you want to use them to fight raiders as they do basically nothing on the zombie enemies.

The melee combat is fun the stamina bar is what kills it entirely for me. It seems like two swings from any weapon will deplete your stamina which makes the combat rather frustrating. While it's fun to hack and slash enemies to bits, but sadly it gets incredibly boring rather fast, not to mention the game is rather long. My first playthrough took me 14 hours to complete every quest and second time completing everything took me 10. 

Verdict:

Dead Island Riptide Definitive Edition is not that great of a remaster and overall the game is really bland and not really worth playing. If you really want to play this then you can do way worse, but for other people, just get Dying Light, it's better in every way, shape and form. 

Final Rating:
5/10

Pros:
+ Hacking and Slashing zombies is fun 
+ Environments are great 

Cons:
- Frustrating gameplay
- Remaster is not that different from the original game

If you liked this review please consider joining https://steamcommunity.com/groups/completingthebacklog and https://steamcommunity.com/groups/ImperialReviews

TLDR: An unbalanced and buggy mess that is too short for the price. Only worth getting (on sale) if you're looking to continue the story.

This game makes it hard to have fun with, because it has a lot of bugs and glitches that have a negative impact on enjoyment. It's very obvious that this game was rushed out of development and hasn't seen much support. It makes this game stink of money grab intentions. This one is rather shameful in comparison to the original Dead Island.

Some combat moves were added that might've been neat on paper but were glitched to hell to the point of being almost useless. You can do a jump attack from above, which is an instant kill to normal zombies, but doing so runs the risk of being stuck in the attack animation. For a few seconds your character is floating slightly above the ground, you can't move, and you are vulnerable to attacks while it's happening. Most of the time, it's not a good idea to use this move.

Another very strange bug prevents Fury from working when it is assigned to a mouse button. I used to have it assigned to the middle mouse button in the original Dead Island, and that worked well. Can’t do it in Riptide for whatever dumb reason.  Actually, Fury is very spotty if you are importing a character. Most of the time the Rage meter just doesn't fill to max, so you can't even use Fury. On rare occasions it actually fills and Fury becomes available. Another bug that you’d think would be fixed in a patch.

A lot of new explosives put in this game, making a lot of variety if secondary weapons. Most of them are good and you can use some good combos with them. One example is using poison bombs to poison the zombies, putting them in a toxic state, which makes them extremely vulnerable to fire damage. You can follow that up with a Molotov, and it's pretty much an instant kill to any enemy. This is a great strategy for tough specials or bosses (though, vast majority of bosses are toxic already, making them incredibly trivial encounters). On the other hand, new to the game are mines, which are great... when they aren't falling under the map when you place them (this happens a lot).

Some of the quest flow is flawed and you may find yourself missing out of quests and their rewards due to it. Such as Harlow’s team quests where you won’t find the items needed for one of those quests until after the quest fails and can’t be completed. A couple of continuous quests are placed in a very out of the way place in the map, making it tedious and undesirable to do it. One of these quests are actually near a fast travel point, but since the devs seemed to have forgotten to add the location to the list of fact travel points, that fast travel point is a one way trip and you have to manually get back to that location. Seems like a silly oversight that shouldn’t have happened, or at the very least been fixed in a patch. On the other hand, now quest rewards scale with level, meaning that continuous quests are a lot more profitable and make leveling up incredibly fast. There's a quest where you won't find the item anywhere in the game except for a single place on the map, and you need three of those things. There are items in the game that have absolutely no use at all (some that are gotten from the more difficult areas in the game).

There’s balance issues in this game that show the lack of testing done with it. A new zombie special called the Screamer is a very annoying addition, particularly if you’re playing solo. They have the ability to make a high pitched scream that stuns your character, making him unable to attack and move very slowly, and it calls every zombie in the area to that location. That’s pretty lethal for a solo player, and seems obvious that it was meant for team play. There is another special that has attacks specifically for a group of players in mind, so not a lot of thought was put in for solo play. Then there is the case that just about all the bosses are in a toxic state, making them extremely easy if you have a fire weapon mod on a weapon. Then you’ll likely have to deal with glitches that allow walkers to one shot a full health bar character with a thrown weapon (died more times to this than anything else). Some weapon drops are so rare that you may not see a single one in a play through. Then you have new additions, like the staff, that are so overpowered that you can essentially finish the complete game with that one weapon. You’ll eventually come across weapon mods very late in the game that are completely obsolete by the time you get them. When walkers with weapons scare you much more than a boss does, you know the game isn’t balanced very well. It creates an experience that is either very annoying or very boring.

Forget weapon farming in this game. Chest respawns are inconsistent and borked and merchants sale the same thing throughout the game with little variation. It makes loot in the game rather dull. Then there were a lot of odd changes to weapons and especially weapon mods that makes you wonder what they were thinking when they designed and balanced weapons. Some of the changes are nice and allow for more modding options. Then others, like the Tesla mod, were nerfed to hell and back. In a game that is supposed to depend a lot on leveling and looting, it seems rather absurd that looting seems like such an oversight in this game.

Also, physics in this game sucks, which makes impact mods rather dull.

There are many more bugs and glitches that make this game a joke and unrecommendable. 

The game also has, perhaps, a fourth of the content that the original game has. This is pretty much an expansion to the original game. Or rather, it plays like act 5 of the original game, starting exactly where the original ends. Yet it is selling for the same price as the original as if it were a fully fledged sequel. I've seen people mistakenly refer to this as "Dead Island 2". The asking price is ridiculous because of that.

Skip this one.

I just finished playing through this co-op with a friend. Years after playing Dead Island and Dying Light, the controls feel extremely clunky and movement is slow and sluggish. Combat however is still a lot of fun, with intense gore and hits that feel like they connect properly.

The graphics have aged very well, with scenic views of distant mountains and nice lighting effects. Gameplay-wise, all you do is kill zombies and do fetch quests, and now and then fight an overpowered boss. Death just means respawning  and losing a bit of cash, but you'll collect so much of it over the course of the game you'll barely notice it. This makes it feel a bit of a pointless mechanic.

In short, I'd recommend this as a fun romp to play with a friend or two, but you'll get bored way before the end if playing on your own. If you haven't played Dying Light yet, prioritise that.

[b]What is Riptide?[/b]

Riptide was a stand-alone expansion to Dead Island back in 2013. Releasing such content was already a rarity at that time; you usually make do with DLCs where your best bet is to purchase the corresponding Season Pass instead of individual contents. So, releasing an expansion to an already well-known game seems a pretty cool idea. The story takes place immediately after Dead Island - from Banoi we switch to Palanai, another tourist resort-like location which is taken over by our undead friends. 

[b]Anything new?[/b]

Yes and no. Yes, as there are some new things in terms of game mechanics but no as they do not significantly alter the gameplay experience. Again, this is an expansion pack so do not expect a completely overhauled and reworked system.  A new addition to the group is John, a 5th member, who is mainly specialised in using brass knuckles. This was the only weapon type left out - we finally have a hero who's expert at hand-to-hand combat.

Another thing is the introduction of survival sections. As our heroes move from one place to another every time just before they begin their journey we are to make a stand. The top of the screen indicates the strength of the horde - naturally, this is decreasing slowly as the zombies are attacking in waves. We can lay traps and put up fences at the beginning and between waves. Using gatling guns to riddle the living dead with bullets is pure fun in these sections.

We also have some new zombie types such as the drowner that quickly wakes up (he is floating on the water appearing to be dead) and attacks you. He is not much of a threat but if you do not pay attention you are in for a nasty surprise. Drowners mean a lot of water - prepare to use not just automobiles but also a motorboat to explore the new island's remote locations. My favourite was the screamer - an old lady whose brain is visible and who is able to emit such a loud scream that your hero starts wandering about while trying to endure the loud noise. There are also some bungalow and apartment areas that are full of zombies and they include bosses - expect a difficult fight but usually great reward at the end.

[b]Why is it Definitive?[/b]

Because it was re-released a couple of years later along with its predecessor. The "normal" versions are not available anymore just the remastered editions. Basically, the game was redone with the use of a later Chrome Engine (the same that ran under Dying Light). It is a nice touch as the game looks much, much better (especially the shadows and some of the lights) but then again you have the same gameplay and some of the annoying bugs or glitches remained.

[b]Who is this game for?[/b]

It is for zombie game fans. Techland's real big hit was definitely Dying Light with its parkour mechanics but if you want to see where the zombie fest started for them feel free to purchase Dead Island and its expansion. Hours of fun are guaranteed!

The original Dead Island was reasonably okay, but Riptide is one of those "sequels" that should have just been labeled an expansion pack - if you already finished the original, there's no substantial changes nor improvements to the gameplay to be found here.
Moreover, where DI's story was at least excusable, what you'll find in riptide is Z-grade writing that will repeatedly lead you to question if the cast can get any more stupid (spoiler: they always can, by a LOT).

As it too often turns out, the first game should have been a standalone instead of an attempt to launch a franchise. Unfortunately for humanity, Deep Silver had no plans to stop at Riptide either...

Trust me, your better off buying Dying Light rather than Riptide. And let me explain why.

 1. There is almost nothing new here asides from a new story and have the same characters and almost the same weapons. 

2. The whole experience as an adventure just doesn't feel compelling and addicting somehow. It's like your backpacking through Europe and you just get tired of doing so after a period of time and decide to stop and rest.

3. The controls and the mechanics are so excruciating and painful that I felt like I was gonna just pass out from exhaustion from trying to get used to them.

4. This is just my opinion really, but the AI are just too OP and getting from place to place feels like more of a chore than a challenge.

So do yourself a favor. Buy Dying Light instead. It may cost you more but It plays almost exactly like Dead Island with only some minor changes to some parts of the mechanics, some new weapons, a new setting as well as a new and more compelling storyline. Plus some parkour. And you rely on alot of that to get anywhere in the game compared to Riptide where your so confused on where to go and struggle to get there.
And I understand people will like different things when it comes to games and if you still want to get Riptide even after reading this. Then by all means go ahead, And just as a friendly reminder, I'm not trying to stop you from buying this, I'm just sharing my opinion.

I don't have a real probrlem with the game, especially since I bought it in the single digits.  On the level of zombie killing on a small sandbox map, it's fine.  It just felt like a game that had everything it needed to say or do in the first one.

Problems:
- NPC comments alone are enough to consider quitting.  You know on hold queues that chime in every 30sec and say "your call is important to us..."?  That are your NPCs.  "Are you still here," every time you walk by them, and the pill junkie who will moan, "Bring me more," if you get within 50' on repeat.
- Frankly, most people in this game compalaining of illness all sounded dopesick to me.
- The clipping is off the hook.  The guy who is your storage container vibrated himself into the floor like he was trying to escape Gorilla Grodd.  When I would back into zomibes with a car, most ended up stuck in it like I was driving the 2008 Kitty Pryde.  I once fought a puple level boss by putting mines on either side of the wall he was standing next to.  When an explosion went off, he would pass thought the wall, hit the next mine, repeat.
- The faces of the people save across the island.  My god.  Was this the closest island to Bikini Atoll?  They all had looks like the island was cused with zombies and horizontal hold issues.
- The swords woman...you're sticking with that skirt and thigh-highs?  That necktie is like an zombie surival OSHA violation.  Not that the rapper guy's outfit isn't making me lose weight just imaging how swamp-ass hot he must be.
- Avoid the drop attack at all cost.  Not only may it be for nothing, but you'll spend about five painful seconds unable to move, like you just stuck the landing and you're waiting for the judges score, as every zombie in 30' beat you like a pinata.
- Rejoice as every drunkenly lobbed projecticle by a probably unseen zomb is a one-hit kill.
- We're still doing the slowly discharging flashlight?  Did it come with the 1998 Trope DLC?
- You know what?  Good voice acting, though.
- There's no persistent state to the whole game.  Screw doing cave/house missions.  Arrived by boat?  Better LoJack that, because you're swimming home when you get out.  You could make yourself rich just walking more than 100' from any pile of luggage, because you can reloot it when you get back.  I sold the same machete stuck in the bad 100x.  It's like Dead Island: Amnesia Island.  Well, except for haunted house staging.  Warp to the marina location....cue the scream...cue the running zombie guy with the blond afro and Nikki Sixx eye shadow.  
- More.

Dead Island: Riptide Definitive Edition is equal to an incomplete game. Don't get me wrong, it has a complete story to it, and it is playable, it's just the constant bugs throughout the game.

When you throw your weapon at an infected, it comes up with a hit marker showing you that you will hit the infected, however, at times when you throw your weapon it will miss completely and go straight past the infected.

The lighting is way to dark, it's as though it's night time despite the sun being bright and shiny. Oh look, a paradox!

Flashlight appears to run out faster than the other Dead Islands, the infected are somewhat far too strong, and the weapons deal almost no damage.

Other than this it's a good game. But y'know, stick with Dead Island: Riptide, as this Dead Island, although being a remake, is just too buggy and feels incomplete. The original Dead Island: Riptide is more complete and holds less bugs than this one.

The Dead Island: Riptide Definitive Edition is both solo and multiplayer by playing with other people or just only with your friends. The game is the same as the original one (Dead Island Riptide) but this one has improved graphics and more realistic enviroments. Also it includes every DLC of the game such as new weapons, new ''skins'' for your character and many more.
The game takes place in some new locations which they were hit by the zombie apocalipse and it continues the events of the previous Dead Island title. The characters who are playable are the same with their unique skill tree and fury but this time a new ''guy'' joins the crew who is almost the God in the game cause he is really difficult to be killed either by zombies or by accidents.

If you like games which has a lot of gore, blood and some sadistic animations and textures, i recommend buying it. The only negative comment in my opinion is that the multiplayer is kinda dead ... not entirely but kinda and if you decide to play with your fellas then they must have the Definitive Edition as well.

I'm going to be brief since I don't feel like writing paragraphs and just make short points instead

1: Bugs on top of bugs. Many from the first game that are still not fixed and some even worse than before. Accuracy is still very very bad and sometimes enemies won't even take damage even when you aimed properly or you'll miss point blank shots. Sometimes your weapons will disappear if you throw them as well. The pathing system is also bugged so you'll have to look at the map to see where you are supposed to be going and hope that you are going in the right direction.

2: Scaling is non-existent. Even if you basically use the new game plus option you are not starting out with a fully upgraded weapon but they treat you like you are and you just die. It got to the point where I stopped fighting the zombies and just ran through them instead unless I had to.

3: Zombies still don't stumble and still cheatand follow through with their animations. This should be an easy fix. If a zombie loses more than 50% of its hp in an attack it should not be able to continue the action. This makes fighting groups of zombies extremely difficult.

4: In new game plus everything is ridiculously expensive. I don't mean to repeat myself but you aren't starting with a wad of cash and your best weapons. You pretty much cannot do anything besides helplessly run and hope that you don't die. There really needs to be a difficulty setting for the game.


Basically to sum this up, if you are a new player then get the first installment of the series and play that instead. THEN decide if you want to spend money on an unrefined game that is basically a continuation of the story.

Edited: I also forgot to mention that zombies with throwing knives can and will one shot you with 0 fucks given. Buy at your own risk because this game is definitely not polished at all.

MAJOR FLAWS in DEAD ISLAND RIPTIDE DEFINITIVE EDITION
    SINGLE PLAYER - The inventory wheel worked in the previous Dead Island Riptide using the mouse wheel. It does not do anything in the Definitive Edition. This means that in SINGLE player mode you must go into inventory (which pauses the game) while you change weapons. The only way that I can accomplish that (actually changing weapons) in inventory mode is to unequip the current item or unequip my intended item then equipping the item I want to use.
    MULTI-PLAYER. The 'gaming network' only looks at other Definitive Edition players - your buddies with the old game can't see you in the network. Also, the inventory issue in single player mode is livable, but in multi-player mode the game CANNOT BE PAUSED - so in combat you can't change weapons without risking death UNLESS you throw your current weapon (which may empty the slot) and some other weapon pops into the slot.
    The Definitive version should not have been released and even if it were free the price is too steep because of the inconvenience in multiplayer. Video - The shadows are blacker when you stand in the sun and the game seems a bit jerky at times - driving a vehicle isn't as much fun for some reason. Other than a little improvement to the video there are NO POSITIVE additions to the game and, of course, the older/better version is no longer available. Oh yes, they renamed some of the descriptions to include 'worn' and other adjectives, but this game is truly worn in its own right.
    DECIDE to return it BEFORE 14 days pass or you MUST PLAY less than 2 hours for a refund. STEAM only refunds based on that criteria - no person involved at their end.

So, I felt like I wanted to play Dead Island, as back in the day when it was released it was fun with friends. Therefore I wanted to revisit this game(playing it single player); unfortunately this game is bad. Here are the reasons why.
Negatives:-
-The stamina bar punishes you so hard that when there is more than 3 zombies around you cant do anything.
-Feels like you are meant to play multiplayer to counter some of the special monster and hordes of zombies.
-The whole game feels clunky(except the driving which is actually well made).
-Due to the stamina bar which you run out of after 4 hits with a mace, I felt constent stress and it wasn't enjoyable. This lead to me just running past everything which isn't fun.
-Please give me the option to get rid of head bobble
-There was a black guy called Harold(I think) who asked for painkillers, he sounded like Harry Potter(this was funny)
-I found myself constently getting stuck in crevasse where I couldn't escape
-The mission feel pointless and make me wonder. *bit of a spoiler, [spoiler] Why can't they just all work together and lift the boat from the swamp area to the ocean?! [/spoiler]
-The minimap didn't show the actually map, it was just bare with the quest marker on, which lead to me having to constently open the map.
-The QTE are always the same, LBM then RMB or E.
-Don't understand why there isn't a block in this game when fighting.
-Some of the animation like the jump on the zombies below you, I didn't understand what the character was doing, and you would be punished more do it as you would be standing still for like 3 seconds while zombies just hit you.
-Killing the special zombies "thugs" is literally just running around in a circle for 5 minutes hitting them.
-Feels like the zombies are super strong in this game, I kept getting on like 10% from 1 zombie combo
-Just feels more stressful than fun.

Positives:-
-Looks nice
-Ran fine
-The ragdoll on the zombies are good when you are fighting them
-Key re-binding is super nice

I was hoping to have fun like I used to on the original Dead Island but instead found it super stressful and would rather play something else. It may be fun with friends but the awkward movement and animations just make it super boring and not engaging.
***I would not recommend this game if you think to play it solo
This is an expansion better then the original game. Feels like its made for  the fans .Totally worth it.

I was looking forward to this expansion to such a terrific game. Sadly though, this one is highly buggy and not worth playing in my opinion. The introduction of "camps" where you can board up the walls and try to control the hordes that attack was an interesting idea but I don't feel it was implemented properly.

Moreover, there is some kind of strange bug where normal zombies are insanely powerful compared to how they used to be. This makes for an extremely tedious battle EVERY time you encounter one and god forbid you encounter more than one at a  time which is all the dang time.

Also, the flashlight button caused the player character to throw out a flare at the same time so you constantly had extremely bright flares all over the place when you turned your flashlight on or off.

I just couldn't look past the weird bugs present in this game and highly recommend you skip over this expansion. If you want more Dead Island action then just replay Dead Island rather than getting this.

This game has its quirks and its bugs, it seems hastily made as an attempt to ride the wave of popularity the original created when it was released.

Pros:

- Game is more fun than the negative reviews lead you to believe. By contrast, it doesn't have the maturity that Dying Light has, however; there are features that I see here that ended up in dying light. (even some of the map icons)

- The game strongly promotes multiplayer, and unlike the first one; there is an emphasis on multiplayer cooperation. In early stages of the game, you are pretty subceptible to death after just a few blows. However, it gets better as your character levels.

- Weapon feel and the skill tree are nice. some of the skill tree items feel not needed, but otherwise it's beneficial.

Neutral: 

- Game has updated engine features, but the same old textures and wire frames. It is dressed more nicely, but technicially not fully modernized.

- Game as others have said is VERY bright and somewhat distracting. There is a sheen to everything in the game; and in dark places, this effect is actually nice and pops the environment more.

- Car handling is ok, the car can be used as a weapon; and due to this I find it to be the most overpowered weapon in the game.

Cons: 

- Zombies literally come at you from nowhere. Not a con for some, but I dislike strongly games that randomly spawn an enemy right next to you just because.

- Melee combat can vary from a side slash to a chopping motion. For some reason, there are so many times I could count that you miss due to the incorrect motion being used for the attack... Conveniently, this depending on your stamina will leave you a sitting duck to be knocked down.

- Lack of cohesion with the story... The story is awful. The showcase to this game is its mechanics. Dying Light blows away the storytelling aspect of the game 10000 fold. The characters are annoying and senselessly vitriolic. You can play the entire game and feel absolutlely no attachment to any of the primary characters or the NPC's. Again, this leads to my "rushed" argument.

Overall:

It is CHEAP right now on the steam store. I would not have bought this otherwise. In a weird way, I am glad I did. You may feel the same way if you played through techland's other gems and want to complete the series. This game isn't terrible. Its just no where near as good as the first Dead Island or Dying Light. Buy cheap, this game isn't worth 19.99 when it feels like DLC.

This is a review about the whole Dead Island series, both normal and definitive editions.

Dead Island and Dead Island Riptide are fine games... BUT only ONCE.
After that, it just get extremely boring, heck, its get boring before the end of the game.
It may be an open world game, but it feels like it's linear as heck.
This is supposed to be a definitive edition of the game, but it is just the same unoptimized piece of crap with a few "instagram" filters, and those "filters" are horrible, it's just plain unrealistic.
I have unfortunately pre-purchased Escape Dead Island hoping it would be good, and to get access to the beta of Dead Island 2, even if we should not pay to play a beta, it should be them who should pay us to play the beta and let them know about the bug and stuff.
But why did I wanted Dead Island 2 in the first place? Did I think it would be any good? Why would it be better?
Hopefully it will, I am not one against good games, of course not! But this series is literally sh**.
It gets repetitive pretty quick, it's a buggy mess, monkeys could probably optimize games better than this.

Luckily for me, I got the definitive editions for "free".
Not really since I have bought the Dead Island games and Escape Dead Island for a total of approx. 65$.
Those games are worth 9.99$ max, Escape Dead Island was worth 4.99$ max at its release, I have bought that crap for what? 50$? Hell yes i do feel cheated.
Luckily for us, no one is forcing us to buy their games.
I have pre-ordered Dying Light too back then, the full edition for approx. 110$ It sure is a good game BUT it is not worth that price either, better than Dead Island, yes, but it still is not enough.
So I'll never be buying any games from them anymore, except if it is really but really cheap.
And you should not either, not an order, just a friendly tip.

If it would be your first time, you could always try it but do not spend more than 3$ for this crap.

[h1] DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review like all my other reviews, if you want a better full review, then please read better reviews then mine [/h1]

[i] Sadly, Dead Island Definitive Edition made me hate zombie games so much that I do not want to purchase the continuation of the story which is Dead Island Riptide because I know for sure that it will be the same as this game. Ignore this game completely... [/i] boy was I stupid enough to buy Dead Island Riptide

Dead Island Riptide is a zombie game developed by Techland and published by Deep Silver, it sort of takes place after the events of Dead Island and continues right after the ending of the first game. Dead Island takes place on Banoi, a party island where people get drunk and turn into zombies, you play one of the four characters in the game and you have to try and survive four acts of zombies and escape the island

Honestly, I do not know why Deep Silver ordered Techland to make a 'definitive edition' because I saw very few improvements but mostly a lot of things were taken out of the game

Dead Island Riptide's gameplay is mostly focused on melee action hence why the gunplay is the worse gunplay I've seen in a game also the driving is the worst I've seen. The only okay thing is the melee action where you bash zombies' brains and bodies

The story and characterization is also really bad. The story was really boring and I couldn't care less about the characters in the game, when there were some 'upsetting' moments I could not shed a tear because the characterisation was terrible also voice acting is bad, many characters trying their best to do Australian and Jamaican accents but fail horribly

This game's optimization is also terrible, for a game that came out so many years ago the 'definitive editon' plays horribly and it took me 20 to 25 minutes to optimize the game to make it at least playable

Sadly, Dead Island Riptide Definitive Edition is just as bad as Dead Island Definitive Edition and Techland and Deep Silver didn't even bother on making it a better version then what it's original was, I'd only recommend the original Dead Island/Dead Island Riptide if you feel like playing a zombie game, otherwise, steer clear away from the Dead Island series and its 'definitive editions'

[h1] NOT RECOMMENDED :( [/h1]

Whoever coded this version did a much better job than the original version. It ran like garbage even on my powerful system, constant stuttering and fps drops due to poor coding. Now the game runs like a dream (i7 3.6gz, 16gb ram, gtx 970) and I can play through it again much more comfortably since they fixed its performance with this release. The regular Dead Island Definitive Edition also fixed the same god awful stutter problem the original game had so get that along with this.

I don't see any glitches so far besides what were in the original game. Yea they should've been fixed in this version because they were stupid glitches but oh well. The game is certainly totally playable and beatable despite them. It's not known for crashing so as pc gamers we can at least be thankful for that considering how suck balls awful a ton of releases in 2016 were.

If you liked DI1 you should like this because it's the same game, new environment. Plus the load times are instant now when in the regular version they were insanely long. Pretty amazing.

With the latest patch, that fixes a game breaking bug that stopped me from playing, I feel obliged to change my review. Right now I recommend this game, BUT it's far from perfect. The biggest disappointment are locations and environment, they are bland and repetitive compared to the first game. And everything being covered in water makes exploration even more annoying. The other very irritating feature are respawning zombies. It's no fun to clear a whole location of enemies just to enter/leave a building and end up being surrounded by them again.

But I still was able to finish it, which means it's not so bad. It's just as fun to try different characters/builds and finding better loot as it was before. It's probably even more fun with friends (too bad I don't have any). If you never played Dead Island, play the first one instead, and if you like it, you can try this.

BTW: Reviews mentioning crashes in chapter 7 are outdated now, the same thing was bugging me, but it was finally fixed.

Lots of weapons and upgrades. Keeps you moving forward just to see whats around the corner or in next crate. Skill tree (that can't be totally filled so choice kinda matters) Character build to suit your own play style. Loot.Loot.Loot. Open world so you can race through with weaponry that works for you or faff about and take your time and test the plethora of zombie killin options. When playing solo I found myself lifting my actual feet off the ground as I jumped onto a ladder with screaming, running zombies hot on my tail. (so glad they are not very good climbers). Solo play through a very different experience than co-op. Much more intense as you have to watch your own back. (Hence the love of ladders and the like). Also the text book horror sound fx keep you on your toes. Was that random shuffle or clonk a zombie or not....

Played this years ago when it came out and now with the Definitive edition, I decided to play it again while I'm waiting for Dying Light 2. I also played through the Dead Island remaster before this. 

If you have a thing for zombies, these and Dying Light are the best games to play. The Definitive versions do look better, with more realistic colouring and lighting, although it gets so contrasty at times it is hard to see.

These editions seem to have fewer zombies in many areas and are much easier to play. There's a leaping attack feature that seems to be new and it catches you out by flinging you off of buildings and platforms when you least expect it.

The voice acting is dreadful and the script pretty bad. The woman leaving diary notes is the only person who appears to have had any acting experience at all. It all shows just how much better Techland got at this when they made Dying Light.

The game has an insane amount of glitches and bugs. There was nothing that stopped me playing although I did have to restart many times to get past invisible thigns blockign doors and vanishing weapons.

None of that killed the game for me and I still found it a good play.

Hey to say this to the game but it is so laggy. No matter how many configurations it still goes at a low frame rate. I even have a graphics processer and it lags. Until changes are made to the game, dont buy this.

This one is harder to review becuase me and my good buddy played the original Dead Island Riptide so buying the difinitve editon for $3.50 we thought was a steal but becuase we played the original and the story line is the exact same it was really boring but im sure people who havent played the original would really enjoy it more but it is also lacking in the small 2 dlc the original had witch was also another turn off

Dead Island Riptide is back with better graphics and smoother gameplay.A pretty chilled zombie killing game. It's easy to drop in and out of but does lack immersion. It's the missing link between RPG and FPS games. 

For those who haven't played DIR before, or those who want to play it again, I would definitely recommend you buy this. However, if you have already played through it a few times, there's probably no point in getting it. 

Pros:
Entertaining Hack'n'Slash combat
Delicious Gore
Beautiful Scenery
Decent character progression
Plenty of weapons to find, modify and upgrade
CO-OP!!! everything is more fun with freinds.
Ability to play again with the same character, skills and weapons.
Open-world ish with quite a lot to explore (I was still finding new things on my 3rd play through)
Loads faster and runs smoother than the original
Very pleased that sniper rifles don't look like toys anymore :D
Added option to turn motion blur off (very nice)
No major bugs (for me at least)

Cons:
Far from perfect storyline
Simple combat can get a little repetative
The new silver blood looks ridiculous
No new fixes, changes or additions (there was a lot that could have been done)
The new lighting is poorly balanced. For me, everywhere is either blindingly bright or pitch black.

IMO: Buy It
Linux must have

The knifethrowing zombies absolutely ruins this game! I have every health upgrade available they still kill me with one throw! The zombies respawn way too fast and way too close! I whipe out a small area only to find that they respawned on the exact same spots as i were minutes ago just killed them. Respawning enemies can be one of the worst things in games in my opinion. Its frustrating and pointless! Respawing enemies is OK only if it doesnt happen too frequently and only if the enemies becomes slimmed down, this is important so that i can feel some sort of accomplishment. If not, killing zombies will feel absolutely pointless! Sometimes the zombies will spawn right in front of your face and that NEVER happened in Dead Island! You save a guy from a horde of zombies and the next time you walk by the same zombies are there trying to grab the guy you saved even though the guy is gone... im like wtf is this? The zombies will be on to you and follow you even though you drive by in high speed, so every time i step out of the car i must fight stragglers, every single time and that gets tiresome so damn fast! Those who hasnt mastered the combat will have a frustrating experience since fast zombies will pop out of every bush on the island and this game makes you realise how bad the combat really is! The zombies are too freaking crowded in this game! I like dead island but this game is boring compared to the first one! Its prettier but no matter how much you pollish a turd it will still be a turd!

This is a fix of my review in order to highlight the many problems.

1. If you choose certain characters, it will crash in chapter 7.
2. There are many bugs in the game, some gamebreaking such as the above, some immersion destroying and some irritating.
3. There is no (absolute 0) support for this game. There is one "Techland" account in the forums, however this is not a real account, as Deep Silver is the developer. Techland has nothing to do with Dead Island bar publishing.
4. If you plan to purchase Dead Island Riptide, my very very major suggestion is to check out key-resellers to try and find a copy of the original. Do NOT buy this version of the game.

5. If you still plan to play this game, the only 100% character to make it through the game is Xian. If you don't plan on playing as her, I 100% recommend that you buy the original Riptide over this.
IT'S GOOD GAME TO PLAY,

EDIT: after many tests (uninstalling HD4000 drivers to force the use of the NVidia card failed too), I have found the culprit: the antivirus software. So, if you have a sort of sandbox activated (like with Avast), it will use nVidia at the first launch, but the second one will use Intel.
So put the game in the exclusions, and it should be ok. (No, don't turn off your AV, you may be at risk)
Some effects still need to be optimized, but all in all, it's ok. A little colourless compared to the original one, so the paradise feeling from the environment is less present.






It is certainly nice with PBR, but it is far from being well optimized, at the contrary of engines like UE4 for example. 
On my computer, UT4 runs smoothly as 50 fps with almost all options at max but the antialiasing. (MSI: I7 3610QM, GTX670, RAM 20Go)
With Dead Island: Riptide DE, all is set to minimum and the better I get is 16fps when in a corridor...

The standard edition is definitely the best choice if you have not a rig with a gtx 980 ti...

Its essentially the same game, but with some graphical tweaks and all the DLC that was released put into one package. If you have the old version of DI:Riptide in your steam libary you can pick this up for $3. If you have played DI:Riptide and feel like you have experienced it to its fullest, there is not really a need to get this as its exactly the same in terms of everything, but graphics. If you feel like playing DI:Riptide again, for this price, why not buy it?                                                                

The game runs wonderfully too. On my PC (Look at specs below) I get upwards of 90-100fps in most scenarios and only see dips when there are a lot of zombies or NPCs on screen. I have not run into any bugs yet either, which is a plus.
I have an FOV fix below if you need help with tweaking your FOV.

(SPECS):
CPU: Intel Core i5-3470 3.2ghz
GPU: EVGA GTX 970 4gb OC'd to 1530mhz
STORAGE: WD Blue 1tb

(FOV FIX): 
**REQUIRES 7-Zip**
-Go into your DI:Riptide directory. This can be found by right clicking DI:Riptide in Libary, select Properties>Local Files>Browse Local Files. 
-Look for the folder DIR then search for Data0.pak. Right click this, hover your mouse over 7-Zip, then click "Open Archive."
-This will bring up a window that says "data". Select the data folder then look for a folder called skills. Open it.
-Look for default_levels.xml and right click it. Select Edit.
-Click CTRL+F and in the box that comes up type "fov" without quotes.
-On the line <prop n="CameraDefaultFOV" v="62.5"/> -- replace "62.5" with desired Field of View (FOV).
-Exit and start game. Play.

Dead Island Riptide Definitive Edition brings to the table what the original Dead Island Riptide had to it, alongside with a lot of new graphics features and advancements. It runs on the all-new Dying Light engine, Chroma 6, which is a large upgrade from the original Chroma 5 engine, and it brings with it a lot of new post-processing effects, making the island look more beatiful than ever. A lot of the models have been replaced, all of the textures have been completely re-done at a higher resolution, bringing more detail to all the characters. The introduction of the new physically based shading teqhnique and photorealistic lighting system brings new life to the island. It's a great game if you loved the original, or even if you didn't. It's worth the $3 it is currently on steam, and even worth the $20 for people who didn't own the original game!
